fields.headline: The best duel scene
fields.standfirst: Shanghai noon
fields.trailText: Shanghai noon
fields.body:
Celebrated bandit Roy O'Bannon (Owen Wilson) has finally been apprehended by Marshall Nathan Van Cleef (Xander Berkeley). As the two prepare for a duel to the death, Van Cleef appears calm, resolved. O'Bannon plays for time, warming up and touching his toes.

"Stop procrastinating, son", Van Cleef snaps. "Come on. Hurry up."

"Stop it! I'm not going to let you cheapen it, alright? This is a duel. It's a sacred thing. It's beautiful."

Roy ceremoniously scatters a handful of sand on the floor.

"It's what separates us from the animals."

He does a few more stretches, before checking the wind direction.

"Phew. I do not envy you. Ready?"

By now, Van Cleef is looking irked.

"Why don't you turn and face me like a man?"

"Why don't you do it your way, and I'll do it mine? How about that?"

The two men face off. Roy is muttering to himself.

"Come on Roy, you can do it.... Ah, no you can't. He's going to kill you."

Van Cleef turns and begins walking to his mark. He takes a step.

"One."

Roy is still talking to himself.

"He's going to blow you away. Aw, come on Roy, don't think like that."

"Two."

"Yeah, be positive. Be the bullet. Be the bullet."

"Three."

"Oh God. I'm going to die."

See also: Duel, Scaramouche, The Raven

Don't see also: Gladiator Cop

Pointless trivia: Xander Berkeley made his screen debut as Joan Crawford's son Christopher in Mommie Dearest (1981) before appearing in two episodes of The A-Team.

webTitle: Leader: Foreign control of stock exchange would not be fatal

fields.headline: Heated exchanges
fields.standfirst:
Foreign control would not be fatal problem

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Does it matter who owns London's stock exchange? In recent years Britain has seen a number of what used to be regarded as key industries, including motor manufacturing and computers, taken over by overseas companies.
fields.body:
Does it matter who owns London's stock exchange? In recent years Britain has seen a number of what used to be regarded as key industries, including motor manufacturing and computers, taken over by overseas companies.

People quite naturally feel a bit queasy when they hear of yet another British institution - this time the London Stock Exchange (LSE) - passing into foreign hands. But queasiness is not by itself enough to block a chain of events that seems to have gathered unstoppable momentum. The story so far is that the plans of the London and German bourses to merge (as a prelude to a global alliance involving others) have been thrown into disarray by what is regarded in the City as a cheeky takeover bid for the LSE from the upwardly mobile Swedish company, OM. Yesterday, the German bourse responded by inviting OM to drop its own £808m bid in order to join the Anglo-German project as another partner. Whatever emerges from all this, one thing is certain: the LSE will never be the same again.

It can hardly complain. It voluntarily demutualised, thereby creating the possibility of a takeover bid. And, in any case, an institution whose raison d' etre is that a free market in shares leads to the maximum economic efficiency can hardly object if the process leads to foreign ownership. That is what happened after Big Bang in the mid-80s, when Mrs Thatcher made a bonfire of the City's restrictive practices. The result was that foreign companies snapped up the City's historic institutions, so that today there are virtually no large domestically owned investment banks.

But because overseas financial companies were attracted to London, a huge number of new jobs were created in the south-east which would not otherwise have existed. The Japanese dubbed this "Wimbledonisation" - after the tennis club, not the football team - because the UK gained considerable economic benefits from staging the event even though most of the players were foreign. The LSE is a relatively small company (the bid values it at less than a quarter of the market capitalisation of Freeserve, the internet start-up) and whoever wins it will still be subject to regulators appointed by the government. If there is a "national interest" at stake here, it is simply to get the most efficient, cost-effective stock market possible so as to maintain and expand the existing customer base. If customers are dissatisfied they will take their shares to alternative bourses or, if they are big enough, trade among themselves. A series of technical problems (including the closure of trading earlier this year) has not given the LSE a reputation for managing technological change well. Maybe OM could bring a sharper technical edge.

A pan-global stock exchange may produce economies of scale but it will also bring with it the dangers attached to monopolies, like keeping prices higher than they should be. In these days of electronic share trading, you do not necessarily need a global umbrella to succeed on a world scale, especially since you are merely trading share certificates. It must also be remembered that foreign take-overs of British assets always attract more publicity than when UK companies and individuals buy assets abroad. Last year, the UK spent £125.3bn in direct investment abroad, compared with inward investment of only £53.3bn. In the first quarter of this year direct investment abroad - at £125.25m - had already matched that for the whole of last year, compared with only £9.8bn of direct inward investment. So we are hardly in a position to complain.

fields.headline: Berlin Philharmonic/ Haitink (Prom 59)
fields.standfirst:
Royal Albert Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Royal Albert Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
The two programmes that the Berlin Philharmonic brought to London this week had a stark simplicity. After the Wagner and Bruckner on Monday night, they paired Strauss's Don Quixote and Beethoven's Seventh Symphony on Tuesday, all four composers at the very core of this great orchestra's tradition.

It's always a revelation to hear these musicians in the flesh: even in the Albert Hall, which can blur and dissipate the most precise sonorities, the transparency and precision of their performances were breathtaking.

One of the great achievements of Claudio Abbado's reign as artistic director has been to make the orchestra a second home for other leading conductors; when Karajan ruled the roost in Berlin, his peers were never so generously treated. Bernard Haitink now conducts there regularly, so when he took over these Proms there was already a familiarity, obvious in the certainty with which these performances unfolded.

From the perfectly poised oboe solo near the beginning of Don Quixote to the unflagging string figuration in the finale of Beethoven 7, everything, one sensed, was exactly as Haitink wanted it. Even the encore, Schubert's Rosamunde music, had the same sublime balance and unforced musicality.

The Russian cellist Natalia Gutman was the soloist in the Strauss, Wolfram Christ her garrulous, viola-playing sidekick, and though she might seem a bit too no-nonsense for the world of dreams and delusions that Don Quixote explores, her sovereign tone and lack of fussiness allowed Haitink to touch in the myriad orchestral detail around her with total security.

Every orchestral effect came across in three Technicolor dimen sions - the battle with the windmills and wind machine; the bleating sheep; the doleful, penitential procession of pilgrims - while Gutman's eloquence in the epilogue was perfectly judged.

Haitink's Beethoven has the same sterling qualities as his Brahms and Bruckner - clear outlines, bracing rhythms, singing melodies. Every Berlin wind principal is a star, but the clarinettist was exceptional, while the strings could command fathomless depths of tone. If the finale wasn't the exhilarating madcap rush that some conductors make of it, Haitink's deliberately targeted energy was hugely potent; he and the orchestra really were on top form.

fields.headline: Part mixed, parts excel
fields.standfirst:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/Jiri Belohlavek
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/Jiri Belohlavek
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Bombay-born soprano Patricia Rozario has become something of a muse for a number of contemporary composers. She inspired John Tavener's The Protecting Veil and Simon Holt cast her as an adulterous sex-kitten in his erotic opera The Nightingale's to Blame. Rozario has now captured the creative imagination of Arvo Part - "the Estonian tintinnabulist" as the programme curiously describes him - sparking off a massive work called Como Anhela La Cerva.

A setting in Spanish of Psalms 42 ("As pants the hart for cooling streams", whence the title) and 43, it was commissioned by the Canary Islands Festival and premiered in Tenerife last year. Though it has much in common with Part's other music - stepwise modulations; an emphasis on cyclic, thematic repetition; a spirit of religious devotion - certain aspects represent a point of departure. The orchestration is uncommonly post-Romantic, with whiffs of Mahler in the string and woodwind writing, Straussian overtones in Part's use of percussion, and shades of Britten and Shostakovich in the brass.

Though the text expresses the anguish of the Jews in exile and prefigures Christ's words at the Crucifixion - Psalm 43 contains the words "My God, why hast thou forsaken me?" - the tone occasionally veers towards a voluptuousness more appropriate to the Song of Songs. The vocal writing is strenuous, exploiting the extremes of Rozario's range: her darkchest register, her ability to let rip in ecstasy high above the stave. She is cruelly taxed by it, taking a while to settle.

It's by no means Part's finest work. His best music asserts spiritual certainty by quelling the intellect with mantra-like repetition. This exerts no such calm, and the response was mixed: Part fans were clearly enthusiastic, while the rest of the audience grew restive.

The remainder of the concert, to a certain extent, made up for it. Richard Goode played Mozart's 25th Piano Concerto with exquisite finesse, though not quite in keeping with Jiri Belohlavek's approach which stressed the piece's forward-looking, proto-Beethovenian aspects. There was another Bach tribute in the form of Weber's orchestration of the Ricercar from The Musical Offering, its austerity a marked contrast to some of the souped-up transcriptions heard earlier in the Proms. Belohlavek closed with Dvorak's Symphonic Variations, an underplayed work of late. With the BBCSO and Belohlavek on top form, it was an exhilarating finale, pure joy from start to finish.

fields.headline: Berlin Philharmonic/ Haitink (Prom 58)
fields.standfirst:
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.body:
This was to have been the start of Claudio Abbado's final visit to the Proms as artistic director of the Berlin Philharmonic, a post he relinquishes to Simon Rattle in 2002. Illness, however, has forced Abbado to withdraw, and his concerts have been taken over by Bernard Haitink a conductor with whom the orchestra has established a considerable rapport.

The programme opened with the Prelude and Liebestod from Wagner's Tristan und Isolde. Haitink is due to conduct the complete work at Covent Garden in October, and this provided us with a sneak pre view. He avoids both the erotic approach favoured by some and the wild prefiguration of Freudian neurosis stressed by others. In their place is something much more spiritual. Haitink seems acutely conscious of the work's philosophical underpinnings - the staining of voluptuousness with Schopenhauerian pessimism, with its emphasis on the futility of human striving and the need for the dissolution of the ego in transcendental experience. He opts for sensuous rather than sexy textures , and presents us with music which seems to emerge from eternity into time and then retreat back into infinity. The famous opening phase slides from silence into sound like the first stirrings of desire slowly taking shape. The Prelude's climax has a frantic urgency, while the Liebestod swirls towards mysticism rather than orgasm. The crescendo and decrescendo through the final chord brings peace and stillness.

It's impressive, moving and profound, though just occasionally there were problems of balance, with the Berlin brass - not quite at their best throughout the evening - tending to be over-dominant.

Bruckner's Seventh Symphony followed. This has always been one of Haitink's great tours de force, though his interpretation has changed and deepened over time. Speeds have become more extreme, with the first movement faster and the Adagio considerably slower than I've heard him take them before. Dynamic and textural contrasts have become more emphatic, and the work's emotional palette has widened.

He still avoids the sensuality that some conductors, notably Riccardo Chailly, have brought to the work of late, though the work's mystic aspects are now balanced by the humane. The great focal Adagio, its composition affected by the news of Wagner's death, is at once a solemn ritual, a vision of transcendence and an expression of the most profound grief; its impact, on this occasion, was shattering.

webTitle: Golden handcuffs for London bankers after Credit Suisse deal

fields.headline: The £800m handcuffs
fields.standfirst:
A huge bonus - or redundancy - for London bankers after Credit Suisse deal
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking group, is to spend $1.2bn (£800m) on sweeteners to retain key staff at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, the smaller US rival with which it has agreed an $11.5bn takeover.
fields.body:
Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking group, is to spend $1.2bn (£800m) on sweeteners to retain key staff at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, the smaller US rival with which it has agreed an $11.5bn takeover.

The golden handcuffs which were being hurriedly put together yesterday, presenting scores of investment bankers in London and New York with the prospect of multi-million dollar bonuses, did little to calm anxieties about the scale of the job cuts. These are expected to amount to as much as 10% of the combined 26,000 workforce in the US and Britain.

The bank tried to play down the extent to which job losses would be felt in London, where DLJ employs 2,000 people after a high-profile recruitment drive in recent years. Joe Roby, chief executive of DLJ, said yesterday: "Each firm needs more firepower in Europe."

The cuts are intended to achieve savings of up to $1bn by 2002 and expected to hit the areas of greatest overlap such as equity sales and trading as well as back office operations in the US and Europe.

The retention package, which equates to half the combined group's annual profits, is expected to be directed largely at a few hundred bankers in DLJ's high-yield and corporate finance departments. CSFB will also pay out options to replace those from DLJ.

But Wall Street was sceptical about the claims over job cuts. One analyst who refused to be named said: "This is not going to be one of the cleanest or easiest of mergers we have seen in the financial services sector."

Amy Butte, financial services analyst at Bear Stearns, said the deal was potentially "ugly" for banking staff. "From DLJ's perspective this is not the best strategic fit because there is so much overlap."

Both banks have expanded aggressively in Europe in the past three years. DLJ recruited Hector Sants from UBS to build an equity research group from scratch within a year of CSFB buying BZW, the British investment bank.

The Swiss bank's success in integrating this business was underlined by supporters to ease concerns about yesterday's merger, which is said to have taken more than two and a half years to hatch.

DLJ maintained a large degree of autonomy under Axa, the French insurer which owns 70% of it. Axa, which also announced its intention to buy the remaining stake in its US financial arm, is to receive $8.1bn for its stake.

CSFB said yesterday that the new group would have topped the league tables for equity and high yield research in the first half of this year and ranked number three in advisory work. DLJ will increase the bank's assets under management by $120bn to $842bn.

CSFB wants to enter the troika of banks - Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch - which control more than 50% of the under writing and mergers business in the US.

In a note to investors, Judah Kraushaar, analyst at Merrill Lynch, poured cold water on these ambitions when he described the merger as "a relatively minimum threat to major US bulge bracket firms".

Only Pershing, DLJ's share clearing arm, will keep its name after the merger, the rest of the business being subsumed into CSFB.

The Swiss bank's purchase of DLJ Direct, the group's online brokerage arm, means it will drop plans to set up its own online brokerage service for wealthy individuals.

fields.headline: Deferential legend
fields.standfirst:
Elvin Jones Jazz Machine
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.trailText:
Elvin Jones Jazz Machine
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.body:
John McLaughlin once said that with Elvin Jones, you get "less and yet more". He was talking about the drummer's habit of playing around the beat instead of upon it, but the same could be said of the legendary Jones himself. He's a diminutive chairman of the board, 70-plus, graciously deferential to the young talent in his band and yet unmistakably the life and soul of the party. His history with Coltrane, Miles and Mingus is folkloric, yet Jones is no snob but a real gent of jazz.

He's not above a moment of mischief, either. "Just in case you're wondering about this hybrid drum set I'm using," he confided, "you can thank or blame Air France, who lost my stuff. It's in lost luggage, or probably South America by now."

He spent a good five minutes introducing his band: Stefano di Batista (saxophone), Steve Kirby (bass), Delfeayo Marsalis (trombone) and Eric Lewis (piano). Then we were away. Your Romance saw di Batista eking out high notes in an energetic warm-up and Marsalis bringing a riper tone and slowing down the melody with triplets, while Lewis worked plenty of rich, bright colours into his unpretentious comping.

The next tune, Mr Jones, written by Elvin's wife Keiko, was highly idiosyncratic and lots of fun. Drums and piano slipped in and out of the groove in a sophisticated emancipation of rhythm while di Batista went on a slightly oriental expedition. webTitle: Merger could cut trading costs by 75%, say exchanges

fields.headline: Merger could cut trading costs by 75%, say exchanges
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of the larger costs of share trading could fall by at least 75% if the London and German stock exchanges complete their merger, it will be announced this morning.
fields.body:
One of the larger costs of share trading could fall by at least 75% if the London and German stock exchanges complete their merger, it will be announced this morning.

In what will be presented as the solution to one of the critical hurdles in the way of the troubled merger, the two bodies which conduct the behind the scenes processing of trades will announce the dramatic reduction in the cost of settling share deals across national boundaries.

The reduction in costs will be in the charges levied by Crestco, which handles processing of trades in London, and Clearstream, which processes trades in Frankfurt, for settling the transactions. It is a cost all the big firms want to see reduced.

The two bodies do not intend to merge as a result of the planned merger between the London stock exchange and the Deutsche Börse, which is being thwarted by a hostile bid for the London exchange by OM, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange.

But they have been working together to help develop the infrastructure needed for a merged exchange.

The cost of settling trades nationally is not expected to be reduced much more after Crest's move earlier this year.

Their attempts to reduce the cost of cross-border trading may come to nothing, however, if OM's bid is successful or other bidders emerge.

Yesterday Deutsche Börse's chairman, Rolf Breuer, indicated that Frankfurt would look for partners for any "white knight" counterbid for the London exchange.

"I would not be in favour of a solely German counterbid. It should be a common effort of all parties interested in the fi nal success of a merger between Deutsche Börse and the London stock exchange, for example our friends in Milan, Madrid, and maybe a couple of others as well," he said.

The Frankfurt exchange is likely to assess the response of the London exchange's shareholders to the OM bid before deciding on whether to launch a counter-strike.

Chief executive Werner Seifert insisted yesterday that a hostile offer was out of the question. "There will never be a hostile bid for the London exchange from us. Why would there be? We are partners."

But OM chief executive Per Larsson attacked the iX plan as "a flawed proposal, a weak proposal" and ruled out the idea floated earlier by Mr Breuer that the door was open for OM to join the iX alliance.

"OM's bid made the case that the iX merger was not good enough, and OM has no interest in joining it," he said.

fields.headline: Euro climbs off floor
fields.standfirst:
Rumours of ECB intervention precede rate verdict

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rumours of intervention by the European Central Bank brought some respite to the euro yesterday as dealers waited anxiously for the outcome of today's meeting to decide interest rates in the euro zone.
fields.body:
Rumours of intervention by the European Central Bank brought some respite to the euro yesterday as dealers waited anxiously for the outcome of today's meeting to decide interest rates in the euro zone.

After lurching close to its all-time low against the dollar of 88.45 cents, set in May, the euro enjoyed a modest recovery, closing in London at 89.26 cents. It also clambered off a record low of 94.05 yen, finishing the day at 95.05.

There was speculation that the ECB might have intervened yesterday as the euro continued to slip against the yen and dollar. Continued weakness of the single currency is causing concern at the bank's Frankfurt headquarters because it is pushing up the cost of imported materials, and thus inflation.

"It seems unlikely ahead of tomorrow's ECB meeting, but nevertheless we are approaching key levels with the euro/yen and euro/dollar at about their all-time lows, so intervention can't be ruled out," said Adam Chester, currency strategist at Halifax bank.

Analysts are expecting the ECB to increase rates by at least by a quarter and perhaps even a half-point today, but higher borrowing costs seem unlikely to rescue the euro. The move has already been largely discounted by the market, traders said.

"What's driving the euro down against the dollar at the moment isn't ECB policies, it's market positioning and merger and acquisition flows," Dresdner Kleinwort Benson currency strategist Jesper Dannesboe said. "So if the euro does react tomorrow this must be blamed on the market and not the ECB."

Expectations that the US economy is heading for a soft landing is driving the dollar's strength against other currencies. It hit a seven-year high of 1.4424 against sterling at one point yesterday. Sterling recovered some ground later in the day, to finish in London at $1.4567.

fields.headline: Jean Toussaint
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
***
fields.body:
The first time I saw saxophonist Jean Toussaint play, he was crammed, all 6ft-plus of him, under the eaves of a poky, smoky pub. It didn't inhibit him in the slightest. He was vibrant, focused, loud.

This time he was playing music from his new CD, The Street Above the Underground, at the Pizza Express Jazz Club. He had only a little more room to manoeuvre, surrounded by a five-strong band plus guest vocalist Noel McCoy.

They kicked off with Blue Funk, drums (Frank Tontoh) and bass (Julian Crampton) forging a heavy, constant beat. Toussaint laid his soaring imprint across it immediately. The Herbie Hancock tune Textures saw him reach for higher notes but hitting one or two disappointingly flat, despite his agility.

Toussaint appears to thrive when hedged in by a repetitive jazz-funk groove. Byron Wallen on trumpet curdled his own melodies around it, riding the beat with liquid fluency. He and Toussaint found some nice juxtapositions, with Toussaint's mix of ease and energy in his melodies up top contrasting with Wallen's echoing, beautifully clear refrains underneath, particularly in a tribute to the pianist Kenny Kirkland.

The Stylistics track People Make the World Go Round saw the band switch into what bordered on Massive Attack territory. Afro, the final number, had something of a calypso feel, with Steve Hamilton on keyboards summoning lush melodies to offset the frenetic rhythm-soldering, and Tony Remy showing his mastery on guitar with a sequence that led back to an exhilarating reunion with the horns.

Toussaint is one of the more laid-back jazz saxophonists. He was once described as "single malt with a vengeance" but in a talented crowd like this his rich flavour was occasionally diluted.

fields.headline: Voicing his opinions
fields.standfirst:
Ken Campbell's History of Comedy: Part One - Ventriloquism
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ken Campbell's History of Comedy: Part One - Ventriloquism
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Ken Campbell's latest loony soliloquy is a bit of a hotch-potch: part celebration of public voice-throwing, part discursive journey through the Ilford maestro's life and times. There are flashes of brilliance but not quite that seamless plaiting together of narrative strands you find in vintage Ken.

He is at his best when he sticks to his theme and plots the strange, eventful history of vent-acts from ancient Egypt to modern times. The creepiest story is of a chap called Walter Lambert who would dress as a night-nurse and project his voice through a child hospitalised after a road-accident. I also liked the account of the ventriloquist's wife who cited her husband's dummy - or "knee-pal" as they're known in the trade - in a divorce suit. And when our hero attends a ventriloquists' convention in Kentucky he comes across a religious chapter that pushes pamphlets with hilarious titles like "Clowning for Christ" and "Bible Verses for Puppets".

I wish the curiosity-collecting Campbell had gone even further into ventriloquial history. No mention here of the Cavalcanti sequence from Dead of Night in which Michael Redgrave's performer is spiritually possessed by his dummy; nor of weird stage acts like Daisy May and Saveen in which the performer's knee-pal was a gingham-clad schoolgirl. Ken is keen that we should revive a declining art and even tests our labial plosives; but, the more he talks about ventriloquism, the more one realises it turns private disturbance into public entertainment.

Like Sterne's Tristram Shandy, however, Campbell clearly believes that digressions are a form of sunshine. Much of the evening consists of recollected autobiographical fragments: transcendent experiences in a sea-scout hut, post-Rada performances conducting pet-memorial services, a lifetime quest for a childhood love called Nina Plashwit who joins an Australian group called Radical Dyke Bikers. Nothing odd is alien to our Ken; but there are times in this protracted show when you feel he is getting higher on performing than we are on watching.

He remains a national treasure, one who is certainly treasured by the National. But, if he is to continue his trawl through the history of comedy, I hope he sticks more closely to bizarre fact and manages to string his potty pearls on a tighter, more visible thread.

Until September 9. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

webTitle: England stars - and understudies - on course for a big pay-day

fields.headline: England stars - and understudies - on course for a big pay-day
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's first gossip column of the week, Charles de Lisle has an exclusive report on how the England team will be raking in £18,000 a man if they win the series against the West Indies, and finds out what Geoff Boycott really said about the Headingley Test pitch
fields.trailText: It won't be uppermost in their minds as the fifth Test at The Oval begins tomorrow, but a series victory would see England's players sharing an ECB bonus of no less than £215,000 - about £18,000 per man for those who've played all five Tests against the Windies.
fields.body:
It won't be uppermost in their minds as the fifth Test at The Oval begins tomorrow, but a series victory would see England's players sharing an ECB bonus of no less than £215,000 - about £18,000 per man for those who've played all five Tests against the Windies.

For the likes of Atherton, Stewart, Caddick and Gough that's a cheque not to be sniffed at, even in these lucrative days. Nasser Hussain (four Tests) should have about £14,000 (minus 40 per cent tax) to spend on, say, a September holiday. Dominic Cork (four Tests if selected tomorrow) will have no trouble paying for his wedding last Monday, or maybe that delayed honeymoon with his second wife.

Even players discarded along the way - Mark Ramprakash, Nick Knight, Robert Croft, Andy Flintoff et al - stand to pick up several thousand pounds each if the series is won.

By winning two Tests the side has already pocketed £60,000, plus £42,000 in prize money from the outgoing sponsors Cornhill, not to mention some extras (Man of the Match awards are worth £4,500). Victory at The Oval would also yield another £30,000 bonus for winning a Test, a further £21,000 from Cornhill, and almost certainly another Man-of-the-Match. All this cash goes into the "team pool", which is split between players under a formula drawn up by them - not their bosses.

The scheme, introduced two years ago, is the ECB's biggest foray yet into performance-related pay. But, oddly perhaps, the bonuses bear no relation to individual performance. They're carved up entirely according to how many matches each member of the team has played. Even 12th men are rewarded as though they'd put in a match-turning performance.

The prospect of yet more bonuses will be good for team morale in other ways, too. Experienced players overlooked for the first batch of central contracts - Graham Thorpe and Dominic Cork in particular - will see them as overdue compensation for the fact that, under a quirk of this season's new pay regime, they're being paid less than was on offer last summer.

This week isn't the first time England's stars have had a serious chance of earning big bonus money. By pulling off that sensational 2-1 victory against South Africa two years ago, they landed a £200,000 performance bonus, then paid by sponsors Vodafone.

Since then, though, a lot of big bucks have gone uncollected. An Ashes series win in 1998-99 would have brought a further £200,000 for the players' kitty, but they lost 3-1. Then there were the twin disasters of the World Cup (partly caused by a pay dispute) and the New Zealand series last summer. The ECB confirms that England's solitary victory, in the first Test at Edgbaston, would have been worth a £19,000 bonus. But the series was lost 2-1, after much anguish, and the series win bonus of £100,000 stayed in the ECB's ever-bulging coffers.

Last winter's South Africa tour (a 2-1 defeat) saw the same pattern re-emerging. The £200,000 series win incentive was never in much danger of being carried off by Hussain's side, though the now-tainted victory at Centurion in the final Test produced £19,000 from the board - and heaven knows how much for the bookies and punters. And the two-Test Zimbabwe series? England's 1-0 win wasn't even deemed worthy of a bonus scheme.

Should England claim the £215,000, it will bring a particular smile to the face of Simon Pack, whose sudden departure as the ECB's first - and maybe last - International Teams Director was announced late last week. The bonuses are his baby. "I prefer not to call this an incentive scheme," he said when the £200,000 for the 1998 South Africa series was announced. "The England team need no such encouragement to give their total commitment. 'Performance -related bonus' is a better description."

Boycott clashes with the committee again

Once again Geoffrey Boycott and the Yorkshire committee are at odds. Boycott privately feels that the committee with which he had so many battles during his playing career is taking his name in vain as it attempts to douse down criticism of the Headingley pitch on which the fourth Test finished in two days.

Against Boycott's clearly expressed wishes, the embattled committee is leaning on the master grafter's reputation to fend off criticism of the cracked wicket on which England bowled out the West Indies for 61. The committee's hitherto undisclosed defence centres - rather surprisingly, perhaps, given that he was fired in 1986 - on Boycott. According to them, a batsman with the technique, determination and experience of Boycott - scorer of 22 Test centuries for England including four in 10 Tests at Headingley, where he averaged 59.80 - would have been perfectly capable of dealing with that surface. Their line is that even against Ambrose and Walsh, Boycott would have been quite able to score "a big hundred".

The actual top score in the match was 76 by another straight-batted Yorkshireman, Michael Vaughan. But in the committee's view, there was nothing wrong with the strip: West Indies' batsmen simply weren't good enough to cope with the moisture in the thundery overhead atmosphere, and the consequent swing.

Boycott, who rarely agrees with anyone, takes a completely different view, and still sounds irritated to have his good name taken in vain. In his view, the wicket was unworthy of a county game, let alone a Test.

During play at Headingley, Boycott - whose duties as a TalkSport radio commentator include pitch reports - paid a rare visit to the committee box, where his private views were made known with customary candour. Returning to the commentary box, believing that hardly anyone had really listened, he blew off steam to fellow broadcasters. Although he withheld news of the committee exchanges from listeners, he told colleagues off air: "I certainly couldn't make a hundred on this bloody wicket. No one could!"

By yesterday Boycott, 59, was a mite calmer. "The pitch was very disappointing," he told me. "England's win was quite exciting and dramatic, and quite exhilarating. But a two-day Test is only all right if it's a one-off. Cricket can't afford more of them."

Could he have prospered on that surface? "Not my problem," he replied briskly, trying to bring the interview to a swift end. Or as he put it: "I'm not going to write your website for you." For that, read tacit confirmation of those private opinions.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For last Friday's Grapevine, with stories on the cricket correspondent who missed Headingley, Shane Warne's long-haul commute to work at Canterbury, cricket's Do of the Week, and why David Gower has become the "new boy" again, click here.

By yesterday Boycott, 59, was a mite calmer. "The pitch was very disappointing," he told me. "England's win was quite exciting and dramatic, and quite exhilarating. But a two-day Test is only all right if it's a one-off. Cricket can't afford more of them." Could he have prospered on that surface? "Not my problem," he replied briskly, trying to bring the interview to a swift end. Or as he put it: "I'm not going to write your website for you." For that, read tacit confirmation of those private opinions. Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com For last Friday's Grapevine, with stories on the cricket correspondent who missed Headingley, Shane Warne's long-haul commute to work at Canterbury, cricket's Do of the Week, and why David Gower has become the "new boy" again, click here.

webTitle: The tough gets back on track

fields.headline: The tough gets back on track
fields.trailText: No one will have viewed Alan Smith's elevation to the England squad with greater interest than the new captain Tony Adams. To say that the wise old head of the back line is not the greatest fan of this precocious young striker would be an understatement.
fields.body:
No one will have viewed Alan Smith's elevation to the England squad with greater interest than the new captain Tony Adams. To say that the wise old head of the back line is not the greatest fan of this precocious young striker would be an understatement.

The scene is Elland Road, May 11 1999, the visitors are Arsenal. Smith, though only 18, is understood to have spent much of the match sledging the admirable Adams, using various aspects of the Arsenal's player's personal life as his subject matter. In the closing minutes Smith is butted by Gilles Grimandi and the Frenchman is sent off.

Old pros have long memories. When the teams met the following season at Highbury Adams made his presence plain to Smith with, shall we say, a personally addressed and particularly lusty challenge.

So when young Smith joins up with England today as a replacement for the injured Emile Heskey, it will be fascinating to know what Adams says to the new boy. Or maybe silence will suffice.

In his short career Smith has always had something to say. Though respect for his betters has not been a theme. Indeed, during one on-field argument the teenager threw the ball into Peter Schmeichel's face.

Smith's reputation as a purveyor of dubious tackles and petulant hostility grew worryingly last season, in which he was booked 10 times and sent off once. His manager at Leeds, David O'Leary, ended up concluding that he was "a bit of a thug". It all added to the Irishman's frustration. Smith had looked like a player to watch when he burst into the Leeds first team with a goal on his debut in a 3-1 win at Anfield in November 1998. Now what he did on the field was making people avert their eyes.

When Manchester City showed interest in signing him in the summer, nobody could have blamed O'Leary for agreeing to the move just to end the hassle. But O'Leary is one of those managers who see difficult players as a challenge. He knew that if he could rid Smith of the bad parts, the good parts - and there were plenty - would be given the room to flourish.

So over the summer the manager laid down the law. "I had big words with Alan and hopefully we have sorted a few things out," he says. "In his first season he did fantastically well but last year he was very disappointing.

"He had a niggling ankle injury but I think a lot of it was him trying to be a different person than he really is. In a way he was trying to show people how hard he was and he was becoming a bit of thug really. And I don't want them in my team.

"But I know Alan Smith and what he's capable of. He has great all-round ability. He can hold a ball up. He's a clever player and can lead the line tremendously well."

O'Leary bases his faith not only on Smith's talent but on his age. "I have to still remember that he is only 19. I had people in this club writing him off when he was 18, which is scandalous because he's a kid. He's going to make his mistakes and have his lows."

O'Leary's little chat worked wonders. Smith has flourished in the early weeks of this season, scoring five goals in four games, and suddenly finds himself in the England set-up with his cockiness hopefully now channelled in the right direction.

"He has the sort of confidence that strikers need," says Kevin Keegan. "That is not arrogance. It is saying, 'I know what I've got to do, I know if I get opportunites I'm capable of scoring goals'."

There have been other signs that maybe at last Smith is beginning to grow up. When the two Leeds United fans were killed in Istanbul last season Smith, born and bred in Leeds himself, wrote on his website about how moved he was. It was a rare sighting of maturity in the teenager. What Keegan, O'Leary and Adams need now is to see plenty more examples.

webTitle: O'Leary urges fans to stay away

fields.headline: O'Leary urges fans to stay away
fields.trailText: David O'Leary yesterday urged Leeds supporters not to return to Istanbul should they be allowed to support the club in the Champions League visit to Besiktas in October.
fields.body:
David O'Leary yesterday urged Leeds supporters not to return to Istanbul should they be allowed to support the club in the Champions League visit to Besiktas in October.

The murders of two Leeds fans in the Turkish city on the eve of United's match with Galatasaray four months ago are still fresh in the memory.

The Besiktas tie prompted Leeds's chairman Peter Ridsdale to begin talks with the Besiktas president Serdar Bilgili, the English and Turkish football associations, the Foreign Office and police before a decision is made on fans.

O'Leary, the Leeds manager, said: "Although I am sure we will get good hospitality, I don't like tempting fate. I just hope nothing happens. I would urge supporters not to go back because it leaves nothing to chance."

O'Leary has abandoned his pursuit of the Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise after the latest negotiations ended in deadlock. The French club had intimated they would accept a fee of £4.5m but O'Leary said yesterday the deal was "dead" after he learned that Monaco were insisting on £6m.

Liverpool confirmed last night that Christian Ziege has finally been registered as their player and so is eligible to play in the Uefa Cup against Rapid Bucharest next month. Middlesbrough, who had bitterly contested the move, initially refused to release his registration papers.

The Barcelona midfielder Ronald de Boer hopes his move to Manchester United "can be agreed soon because it would be a really great move for me. I do not seem to have a future at Barcelona and so may have to look elsewhere." The Dutch international would cost in excess of £5m.

The Scotland coach Craig Brown is confident that the midfielder Paul Lambert will be fit to face Latvia on Saturday despite a groin injury.

Neil Lennon was being checked by the Northern Ireland team doctor in Belfast yesterday to verify Leicester's claim that he is injured and cannot face Malta on Saturday.

Willie Maddren, the former Boro central defender and manager , died in his sleep yesterday aged 49 after a long fight against motor neurone disease. He leaves a wife, Hilary, and four children.

fields.headline: West Indies left in disarray
fields.trailText: Comings and goings in the West Indies camp yesterday can have done nothing to settle nerves as the tourists prepared to try to square the series.
fields.body:
Comings and goings in the West Indies camp yesterday can have done nothing to settle nerves as the tourists prepared to try to square the series.

A sunny day in London saw the unfit Shivnarine Chanderpaul flying home, the fast bowler Reon King ruled out with a stress injury of the instep and the youthful revelation of the series, Ramnaresh Sarwan, having his first bat since returning from Guyana following a family bereavement - and just for good measure Brian Lara was clean bowled in the Oval nets by a 22-year-old slow left-armer from Weybridge, Giles Puckle.

But Franklyn Rose ran in well without the strapping he needed on his problem ankle in Monday's friendly against a Sir Paul Getty X, and so it looks as if West Indies could pick two from Rose, his fellow quick Nixon McLean and the legspinner-batsman Mahendra Nagamootoo, who scored a century in the recent embarrassing defeat by Somerset.

It had been hoped that Chanderpaul, a solid presence in the middle order, would recover from the tendinitis in his right elbow that had kept him out of the third and fourth Tests, but it was not to be.

The team manager Ricky Skerritt said: "He's had the best possible care, quality specialists have looked at it and we were given the OK for him to test it out in the game at Somerset. "He had a little discomfort and some pain. He just wasn't happy."

Sarwan, the one batsman England could not dismiss in the fourth Test, was welcomed back by Skerritt. "We think he is ready. For a young man going home for a death in the family it's not easy and we are going to do everything to help him through. Sarwan has been a breath of fresh air, very promising and good for the future of cricket."

webTitle: Bitter Croft lashes out at selectors

fields.headline: Bitter Croft lashes out at selectors
fields.trailText: As England's cricketers prepared for what would be a historic series victory over West Indies, the management came under an astonishing attack from Robert Croft.
fields.body:
As England's cricketers prepared for what would be a historic series victory over West Indies, the management came under an astonishing attack from Robert Croft.

The Glamorgan all-rounder, who was not a conspicuous success in the two Tests he played against West Indies, is peeved that he was not contacted by the selectors before his name was omitted from the squads announced over the weekend, and he all but resigned from international cricket.

"Whether it's my choice or theirs, I don't think I'll play for England again," he said. "I don't want it to sound like sour grapes, or have people thinking there goes Crofty whingeing. I wouldn't have been available anyway for selection this winter.

"I've always had plenty of enthusiasm to play the game but that has been knocked out of me on the Test stage this summer. I feel like a boxer who has taken too many blows. I keep getting off the canvas but it becomes harder every time you're knocked down. The worst thing is I believe the selectors take notice of what is written in the papers.

"People talk about the new England regime but I don't think it's changed a lot. I didn't even know the squad was being announced. I didn't even get a phone call to tell me I wasn't in it.

"I don't think Glamorgan players are given the chance to prove themselves at international level. Some people like Gough, Caddick and Stewart are cemented no matter what they do. I've never been fortunate enough to have that. I've always been looking over my shoulder, worrying about my place."

If Croft is expecting a wave of How Green Is My Valley-style sentiment he may be disappointed. This is not the first time a whinge in the willows has come from this particular direction and to compare himself with such established Test players as Alec Stewart, Andy Caddick and Darren Gough is frankly ridiculous. The Glamorgan opener Steve James has more cause for complaint.

Croft first played for England in 1996 and though he briefly looked the part in New Zealand three years ago he has failed to establish his place after 17 appearances. He has taken 39 wickets at 39.92 with his off-spin and has passed 30 only twice in 27 innings.

He played two Tests against West Indies this summer. In the first Test, at Edgbaston, he scored 18 and one and had figures of 29-9-53-2. In the third, at Old Trafford, he scored an unbeaten 27 but his disappointing bowling was reflected in his figures of 47-8-124-1.

If Croft appeared to keep the door ajar on his England career Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, appeared to kick it shut. Fletcher, Glamorgan's coach in their championship year of 1997, said yesterday: "Robert has made this decision and I hope that in the future he will not look back and say it's a rash one. He must hope he has not made it too early."

 Shivnarine Chanderpaul will not be staying for the fifth Test . The West Indies batsman is returning to Guyana after being sidelined with a nagging forearm injury.

webTitle: Rangers in rush to sign Hartson

fields.headline: Rangers in rush to sign Hartson
fields.trailText: John Hartson was last night hoping to revive his fortunes with the most surprising move yet of his turbulent career as Rangers worked feverishly to finalise a £7m deal against the clock.
fields.body:
John Hartson was last night hoping to revive his fortunes with the most surprising move yet of his turbulent career as Rangers worked feverishly to finalise a £7m deal against the clock.

The Welsh striker's elevation from relegated Wimbledon to the champions of Scotland was hinging on a stringent medical in Glasgow which must be completed and passed by this morning if the 25-year-old player is to become a Rangers player in time to beat the deadline for the Champions League.

Indeed the Rangers chairman David Murray, who has been a long-time admirer of the fiery striker, admitted that the time pressures could scupper the deal, the FA of Wales having insisted earlier that he rejoin the national squad in time for a 10am flight today to Minsk before Saturday's World Cup qualifier with Belarus.

Murray, who quickly agreed personal terms with Hartson, said last night: "There is the possibility that the medical might not go well because it is very strict.

"We would ask him to stay a bit longer tomorrow, but he has to catch up with the Welsh squad in Belarus and that might stop us doing a full medical - and if that is the case then it is a possibility that the deal will be off.

"We have made mistakes in the past and we don't want those things to happen again. But he is staying here tonight."

Hartson earlier talked passionately about his willingness to join the Ibrox cause - "there is nothing bigger than Rangers" - but was then facing the potential distress of another major move breaking down after his projected £6m transfer to Tottenham in March was scuppered by a medical uncovering knee trouble.

If Hartson passes this medical he will join another recruit, the Dutch international midfielder Ronald de Boer, who has already passed a medical and said last night that he was "to all intents and purposes a Rangers player" after denying his £6m move from Barcelona had stalled. Dick Advocaat, Rangers manager, revealed De Boer had opted for Ibrox because Sir Alex Ferguson could not guarantee the player a first-team place at Old Trafford. Advocaat added: "I have always been an admirer of De Boer, but normally a player of his quality would not want to come to Rangers."

fields.headline: Two-metre terminator's final act
fields.standfirst: Mike Selvey salutes the demolition man, Curtly Ambrose
fields.trailText: When the West Indies under pressure,
fields.body:
When the West Indies under pressure,

Who's the man who never surrenders?

Curtly, the Master.

He makes the batsman shiver

When he run up to deliver

Curtly, the Master.

What was to become arguably the most devastating spell of bowling in Test history came from modest beginnings. It was early afternoon on the penultimate day of January seven years ago and, at the Waca in Perth in the final Test of a tumultuous summer, David Boon and Mark Waugh were laying the groundwork for the sort of total that would see Australia become the first side in 14 years to unseat West Indies in a series.

Only four days earlier in Adelaide, Curtly Ambrose had bowled himself into the deck, taking 10 wickets in the match before Courtney Walsh dredged up the last Australian wicket when two more runs would have clinched the series. "I was interested to hear Michael Holding say that Curtly is still learning," said Allan Border pithily afterwards. "I hope he doesn't learn too much more." Prescient words.

Ambrose had looked spent, and now - in the heat of Western Australia - 12.4 overs had brought him no wickets for 24 runs. But the Fremantle Doctor, the breeze that blows across the city from the ocean, had begun to puff its cheeks. With this over his shoulder, Ambrose strode in once more. Waugh edged and the wicketkeeper Junior Murray took the catch.

It was a catalyst. Before the eyes of a disbelieving crowd, Ambrose dismembered the Australians with seven wickets in 32 balls, delivered at high pace and of impeccable line and length: Boon taken in the slips, Border first ball at the wicket, Ian Healy caught at slip, Merv Hughes at cover, Damien Martyn also at slip and big Jo Angel another victim for Murray. The last man dismissed, Shane Warne, was run out, otherwise Ambrose would surely have collected another.

Somewhere in the middle of the carnage, Martyn got a thin inside edge on to his pad and the ball trickled past Desmond Haynes at short-leg. It was the only run Ambrose was to concede in the spell. Back home in Swetes Village, a small community in Antigua's parched interior, Ambrose's mother - whose habit was to march out of her house and ring a hand bell each time her son took a wicket - might have been the St John's fire brigade in an emergency.

Less than two days later West Indies had wrapped up the match by an innings and Ambrose, seated in the maroon 4x4 that he had won as International Cricketer of the Year, and with a smile the width of the Caribbean, was careering his way joyously round the boundary, horn blaring, the entire team clinging on.

It had been miraculous bowling, each victim greeted with arm-pumping, fist-flailing celebration, but it required no aerobatics from the ball. Ambrose simply did what he had done since his debut in Georgetown five years earlier: bowled unfailingly in the right place with uncommon bounce from his great height (the Aussie press delighted in referring to him as the "two-metre Antiguan") and a hint of movement. The ball was drawn magnetically, mesmerically, to the edge of the bat. That one spell encapsulated almost everything of Ambrose: pace, skill, accuracy unparalleled in a genuinely fast bowler, aggression, courage and the capacity to produce devastating bursts of wickets when the integrity of West Indies cricket was at stake.

In 1990, he sent England spiralling to defeat in the final session in Bridgetown, taking five for 18 in a 7.4-over spell with the second new ball that brought his best Test figures of eight for 45. Four years later, as England began a victory charge on a Port-of-Spain evening, he nailed Mike Atherton first ball, took six for 22 in 7.5 overs and reduced the tourists from optimism to 40 for eight and helplessness. In between times, his six for 34 demolished South Africa in the inaugural Test between the two countries, when it seemed certain West Indies would lose.

All but three of Ambrose's 97 Tests have been in the company of Walsh. In those games the pair have taken 752 wickets - 386 of them to Ambrose - a combination that has never been matched.

Enough is enough

His total of 402 wickets (including 161 against England) comes at an average of 20.96, bettered only by Malcolm Marshall of those 23 bowlers who have taken 250 Test wickets. Among the same group his economy rate, runs conceded per over, is inferior only to three spinners: Lance Gibbs, Derek Underwood and Bishen Bedi.

Of modern fast bowlers only Joel Garner, because of his great height, Wasim Akram, for a whole variety of reasons, and perhaps Waqar Younis, with the reverse-swung old ball, have been so awkward. He gives nothing, reducing batsmen to indiscretion in pursuit of any runs. Forward is the way to go but not an option.

As with Garner, his height appended by the length of his arms produces a foreshortening effect, an illusion that he is a normal-sized bowler delivering from 10 feet closer. A batsman trained to look in a certain area for the ball finds himself searching above his normal focal point and Atherton, for example, has prepared for West Indies series by using a bowling machine with extendable legs.

Ambrose is 37 next month, though, and tired. The fire still burns, but he is weary of shoring up West Indies. His disappointment at the lack of successors clearly rankles. Attempts have been made to coerce him into one last hurrah in Australia, but he has resisted. Enough is enough, he says. This is it. No mas. The end of an era.
fields.bodyText: When the West Indies under pressure, Who's the man who never surrenders? Curtly, the Master. He makes the batsman shiver When he run up to deliver Curtly, the Master. What was to become arguably the most devastating spell of bowling in Test history came from modest beginnings. It was early afternoon on the penultimate day of January seven years ago and, at the Waca in Perth in the final Test of a tumultuous summer, David Boon and Mark Waugh were laying the groundwork for the sort of total that would see Australia become the first side in 14 years to unseat West Indies in a series. Only four days earlier in Adelaide, Curtly Ambrose had bowled himself into the deck, taking 10 wickets in the match before Courtney Walsh dredged up the last Australian wicket when two more runs would have clinched the series. "I was interested to hear Michael Holding say that Curtly is still learning," said Allan Border pithily afterwards. "I hope he doesn't learn too much more." Prescient words. Ambrose had looked spent, and now - in the heat of Western Australia - 12.4 overs had brought him no wickets for 24 runs. But the Fremantle Doctor, the breeze that blows across the city from the ocean, had begun to puff its cheeks. With this over his shoulder, Ambrose strode in once more. Waugh edged and the wicketkeeper Junior Murray took the catch. It was a catalyst. Before the eyes of a disbelieving crowd, Ambrose dismembered the Australians with seven wickets in 32 balls, delivered at high pace and of impeccable line and length: Boon taken in the slips, Border first ball at the wicket, Ian Healy caught at slip, Merv Hughes at cover, Damien Martyn also at slip and big Jo Angel another victim for Murray. The last man dismissed, Shane Warne, was run out, otherwise Ambrose would surely have collected another. Somewhere in the middle of the carnage, Martyn got a thin inside edge on to his pad and the ball trickled past Desmond Haynes at short-leg. It was the only run Ambrose was to concede in the spell. Back home in Swetes Village, a small community in Antigua's parched interior, Ambrose's mother - whose habit was to march out of her house and ring a hand bell each time her son took a wicket - might have been the St John's fire brigade in an emergency. Less than two days later West Indies had wrapped up the match by an innings and Ambrose, seated in the maroon 4x4 that he had won as International Cricketer of the Year, and with a smile the width of the Caribbean, was careering his way joyously round the boundary, horn blaring, the entire team clinging on. It had been miraculous bowling, each victim greeted with arm-pumping, fist-flailing celebration, but it required no aerobatics from the ball. Ambrose simply did what he had done since his debut in Georgetown five years earlier: bowled unfailingly in the right place with uncommon bounce from his great height (the Aussie press delighted in referring to him as the "two-metre Antiguan") and a hint of movement. The ball was drawn magnetically, mesmerically, to the edge of the bat. That one spell encapsulated almost everything of Ambrose: pace, skill, accuracy unparalleled in a genuinely fast bowler, aggression, courage and the capacity to produce devastating bursts of wickets when the integrity of West Indies cricket was at stake. In 1990, he sent England spiralling to defeat in the final session in Bridgetown, taking five for 18 in a 7.4-over spell with the second new ball that brought his best Test figures of eight for 45. Four years later, as England began a victory charge on a Port-of-Spain evening, he nailed Mike Atherton first ball, took six for 22 in 7.5 overs and reduced the tourists from optimism to 40 for eight and helplessness. In between times, his six for 34 demolished South Africa in the inaugural Test between the two countries, when it seemed certain West Indies would lose. All but three of Ambrose's 97 Tests have been in the company of Walsh. In those games the pair have taken 752 wickets - 386 of them to Ambrose - a combination that has never been matched. Enough is enough His total of 402 wickets (including 161 against England) comes at an average of 20.96, bettered only by Malcolm Marshall of those 23 bowlers who have taken 250 Test wickets. Among the same group his economy rate, runs conceded per over, is inferior only to three spinners: Lance Gibbs, Derek Underwood and Bishen Bedi. Of modern fast bowlers only Joel Garner, because of his great height, Wasim Akram, for a whole variety of reasons, and perhaps Waqar Younis, with the reverse-swung old ball, have been so awkward. He gives nothing, reducing batsmen to indiscretion in pursuit of any runs. Forward is the way to go but not an option. As with Garner, his height appended by the length of his arms produces a foreshortening effect, an illusion that he is a normal-sized bowler delivering from 10 feet closer. A batsman trained to look in a certain area for the ball finds himself searching above his normal focal point and Atherton, for example, has prepared for West Indies series by using a bowling machine with extendable legs. Ambrose is 37 next month, though, and tired. The fire still burns, but he is weary of shoring up West Indies. His disappointment at the lack of successors clearly rankles. Attempts have been made to coerce him into one last hurrah in Australia, but he has resisted. Enough is enough, he says. This is it. No mas. The end of an era.

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: Devon Malcolm's ignominious season hit a new low yesterday when he parted ways with Northamptonshire by mutual consent.
fields.body:
Devon Malcolm's ignominious season hit a new low yesterday when he parted ways with Northamptonshire by mutual consent.

The once-fearsome former England fast bowler, who took 119 wickets in 36 Tests - including his famous nine for 57 that bowled England to a series-equalling victory against South Africa in 1994 - has been restricted to Northamptonshire's second XI since July in a sad end to his three-year contract at Wantage Road.

The future looks bleak for the Jamaican-born Malcolm, now 37, but he insisted last night that it was not the end of the road.

"I'm still pretty fit and it's a case of examining all my options before deciding what to do next," said the veteran of 912 first-class wickets. "Ideally I would still like to carry on playing for someone, and there has already been interest from other counties."

All was not well at fellow Second Division side Glamorgan last night either, despite appearances to the contrary. The club's official website contained a message from the captain Matthew Maynard praising Steve James' triple-century last week and urging fans to "support the club as we push for promotion". Behind the scenes, however, the Welsh county was awash with the news that Maynard had quit as captain.

fields.headline: Irish duo are sent home
fields.trailText: Mark Kennedy and Phil Babb were yesterday sent home in disgrace from the Republic of Ireland squad to face Holland on Saturday after being charged with damaging a policewoman's car after a late-night drinking session in the centre of Dublin.
fields.body:
Mark Kennedy and Phil Babb were yesterday sent home in disgrace from the Republic of Ireland squad to face Holland on Saturday after being charged with damaging a policewoman's car after a late-night drinking session in the centre of Dublin.

After a night in police cells they appeared at the Dublin district court to face charges of criminal damage, causing a breach of the peace and being drunk and disorderly.

Mick McCarthy sat in the public gallery as they were bailed until November 13, and the Republic's manager immediately informed the Football Association of Ireland of his intention to send them home.

"I wanted to speak to the two lads before anyone else and I'm sure my words will still be ringing in their ears," he said.

"They are no longer members of the squad and will not be travelling to Holland. The decision was mine and it was fully supported by the FAI."

Kennedy, the 24-year-old Manchester City winger, and Babb, 29, the defender who joined Sporting Lisbon from Liverpool at the end of last season, were arrested by an off-duty policewoman who allegedly caught them jumping on her private car at 4am.

Before leaving the team hotel yesterday they appeared at a news conference. "I regret everything. I apologise to the manager, the players, my family and my girlfriend. I am absolutely gutted about what happened; it's the lowest point of my career," said Kennedy, looking close to tears.

"I have to be responsible for my actions. It was a prank that got out of hand. I apologise to the young lady concerned for doing damage to her car."

Babb said: "It is sad for both of us, especially before such a crucial World Cup game. It's very hard being here in front of all the media. I am deeply sorry for what happened. I apologise to my team-mates and everyone involved in the incident."

Brendan McKenna, the FAI press officer, described the incident as "a couple of pints becoming a couple more pints."

Kennedy also faces disciplinary action by his club. "On the face of it, it is very disappointing but we will have to wait until the full facts emerge," said City's manager Joe Royle.

Eircom Plc, the former state-owned telecommunications company, is the new sponsor of the Republic team, taking over from Opel. The new backing runs until 2012 and is part of a £14.3m package deal.

webTitle: Fingers crossed for a flat track

fields.headline: Fingers crossed for a flat track
fields.trailText: Exactly five years ago, West Indies and England approached the Oval at the end of a ding-dong Test series in which England had a sniff of ending their melancholy sequence of failure in the Wisden Trophy, dating back to the days of a two-bob pint and a tanner's worth of chips.
fields.body:
Exactly five years ago, West Indies and England approached the Oval at the end of a ding-dong Test series in which England had a sniff of ending their melancholy sequence of failure in the Wisden Trophy, dating back to the days of a two-bob pint and a tanner's worth of chips.

In 1995 the score was 2-2 with one to play, so England were desperate for a result pitch. Paul Brind, the Surrey groundsman, was new, and apparently petrified. He served up a surface that would not have produced 40 wickets in a fortnight. West Indies scored nearly 700 (more than 10 times their current going rate) and the game died a peaceful if infuriating death under deep anaesthetic. Even Graeme Hick made runs.

Tomorrow the parties reconvene at the same place. This time, common sense, economics and partisanship all demand a similar sort of pitch. Cock-up theory - the most reliable guide to English cricket in the 31 years since an England captain last lifted this trophy - would suggest a green flyer. Surrey assure us otherwise.

If they are right, it will be another hint that the game here is at last producing intelligent thought. Of the present squad only Atherton, Thorpe, Cork and Hick - the Widmerpool of cricket - were in the 1995 game, and some of their team-mates then were way short of genuine Test quality. Tomorrow, the players will go out inspiring more confidence in both the public and one another than any England team since Ian Botham's pomp two decades ago, and even his confidence deflated in seconds whenever West Indies were the opposition.

There are still three great West Indian cricketers: Lara, Walsh and Ambrose. What has been so astonishing has been the abysmal standard of the other eight.

A regular bar-room exercise at this stage of a tour is to pick a notional eclectic team from the combined XIs. Traditionally this ends with someone flatly declaring that not one England player would get into the other side. Now, the big three aside, not one of the West Indians would be sure of a place in the England team. It is an astonishing turnaround. We now have an England fourth seamer, Craig White, who can bowl straight at 90mph when the West Indian back-up attack could not be trusted to aim straight at a garage door.

So what is the bigger factor: English improvement or the opposition's decline? I hate to say it, but the utter failure of the younger West Indians (excepting the hints of promise from Sarwan and Hinds) has to be regarded as the crucial element. They have allowed England to play. But England's success thus far has not just been a matter of results. At last, there does seem to be a genuine change of attitude.

Inevitably people are praising Duncan Fletcher, the England coach. There is nothing harder in sports journalism than to measure accurately the input of a coach: outsiders see only fragments of what is happening, insiders are often unreliable guides. But for years new players have emerged from the England dressing room looking underprepared and over-wrought. The team motto might have been borrowed from Corporal Jones. Players of obvious ability (Hick and Ramprakash, most glaringly) have done headless-chicken impersonations time and again.

This year, Vaughan, Trescothick and White have come out and played their cricket without fear. England are now run by two men - David Graveney and Duncan Fletcher - who seem to possess inner calm. It has been transmitted to the squad.

But it has taken a long time to get here. If the nadir in terms of results was only 12 months ago, when New Zealand won at the Oval, the organisational nadir was probably in 1988, when Peter May contrived to get his godson Chris Cowdrey appointed captain.

Since then, a lot of men have put in a lot of effort to make England less shambolic. Micky Stewart, the first team manager, and his captain Graham Gooch introduced the work ethic; the much-derided Ted Dexter pioneered the structure of A-tours and age-group cricket; David Lloyd brought England up to speed with modern coaching methods.

Now we may be getting somewhere. I can't say I predicted it: 30 years on Devil's Island would hardly poison the optimism as much as 30 years watching English cricket. And always remember that the West Indians are proven escapologists. But England need this series. They deserve it too.

webTitle: Big Brother website is a blockbuster

fields.headline: Big Brother website is a blockbuster
fields.standfirst:
<A HREF="http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/bigbrother/"Special report: Big Brother
Net news
fields.trailText: Bigbrother.terra.com, the website which broadcasts round the clock surveillance of Channel 4's Big Brother house, was one of the most popular websites in Britain last month and has contributed to a four-fold surge in traffic to the main Channel 4 website, writes Mary O'Hara
fields.body:
Bigbrother.terra.com, the website which broadcasts round the clock surveillance of Channel 4's Big Brother house, was one of the most popular websites in Britain last month and has contributed to a four-fold surge in traffic to the main Channel 4 website .

A report from internet research company MMXI Europe, which tracks 85% of internet traffic worldwide said the site had shot in at number 26 - ahead of many household names including Lastminute.com and Tescodirect.com. Some 8.1% of people with home access to the internet visited the site in July.

The Big Brother website has pivoted the main Channel 4 website to 34th place in the table, ensuring one of its best months to date with a 6.9% reach.

A Channel 4 spokesman said: "We knew it would drive traffic through but it was not the reason for doing it."

He said the station had set no targets for either TV ratings or visits to the web site but was obviously pleased with the outcome.

Paul Munford of Victoria Real, the company which built and manages the Big Brother website, said: "It has surpassed our wildest dreams. The site only went live on July 14th so any figures will be an underestimation."

He said the figures for August would be bigger, especially around the time of Nasty Nick's departure, which was shown live from the site on a video screen in Leicester Square.

Mr Munford said the site would be more than able to cope with any further surges in traffic as the show reaches its climax in the coming weeks.

Bigbrother.terra.com is the only website in the top 30 for a single entertainment vehicle. Just two established media sites, BBC.co.uk and Virgin.net, have made the top 30 taking up numbers 10 and 18 respectively. Top of the table is MSN.com which reached 38.3% of the potential internet audience.

fields.headline: Johnston Press buoyant as profits leap
fields.trailText: Regional newspaper publisher Johnston Press has posted improved half-year results, building its war chest in readiness for a possible takeover battle for rival Regional Independent Media.
fields.body:
Regional newspaper publisher Johnston Press has posted improved half-year results, building its war chest in readiness for a possible takeover battle for rival Regional Independent Media.

The Edinburgh-based group boosted pre-tax profits profits from £25.9m to £35.2m, beating analysts' forecasts, which anticipated figures of £33m.

Johnston is the UK's fourth biggest regional newspaper group, with nearly 200 titles and 54 websites. It will be told by regulators in October whether it can bid for RIM, the owner of Yorkshire Post and Sheffield Star, with US publisher Gannett and the Guardian Media Group also interested.

Johnston shares rose 1.25p to 371.5p on Wednesday (30 August), after hitting an all-time high of 390p in early trading.

fields.headline: Steep learning curves
fields.standfirst: Periodic updating of skills is on the cards for social workers
fields.trailText: Periodic updating of skills is on the cards for social workers.
fields.body:
The government yesterday announced proposals for the testing of social workers to establish whether they have updated their professional training and have sufficient knowledge and practical skills to do the job properly. In a consultation paper on improving the quality of social care, ministers raised the possibility of a periodic MoT test for Britain's 25,000 qualified fieldworkers, similar to the five-year revalidation scheme proposed by the General Medical Council to check the competence of doctors.

If the plan is adopted, the implication is that continuing professional development will become a condition of holding on to a job in one of the country's most overstretched workforces. "It is no longer acceptable to assume that a qualification gained at age 25 or 30 will equip professional staff for the challenges they face 20 years later," says the paper, A Quality Strategy for Social Care. "We will set out to encourage a step change in attitudes to, and participation in, post-qualification training."

The pending scheme for registering professional staff with a general social care council (GSCC), already promised by Labour, could be used to ensure their skills are regularly updated, the paper suggests. Promotion to supervisory positions "could be made dependent on the attainment of post-qualifying training" and there could be a more widespread check on the skills of field workers. "The government would welcome views on whether the general social care council should be asked to develop a formal re-registration scheme for professional staff, in the same way that the GMC has recently introduced such a requirement for doctors."

The proposal was part of a radical overhaul of social work training, based on a report by JM Consulting, commissioned by the Department of Health in 1998 and published yesterday alongside the consultation paper. The consultants recommend "a significant upgrading of several aspects of the qualifying education, with a greater focus on field experience, based on a national curriculum for social work training".

Instead of 80 colleges offering two-year diploma courses of variable quality, the consultants think there should be a much smaller number of centres of excellence offering three-year courses of degree standard. The consultation paper does not indicated whether ministers agree that social work should be turned into a graduate profession. But John Hutton, social care minister, sounded keen when he floated the idea at a conference in London in July, organised by the Guardian and the National Institute for Social Work.

The paper raises the obvious worry that increasing entry standards might reduce the supply of newly qualified social workers. A possible solution might be to retrain other social care staff who were capable of more skilled work.

Other proposals include a social care institute for excellence (Scie) to provide authoritative guidance on good practice. Ministers are canvassing opinion on whether it should be a not-for-profit voluntary body, at arms length from government; a statutory, non-departmental public body funded by government; or an adjunct of either the new national care standards commission or the GSCC.

Hutton says: "With up to 1.5m people relying on social services in England, we must have a system which is robust and of the highest quality... This strategy offers anyone who cares about social services a real opportunity to make radical changes. It must be grasped."

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, says the profession should welcome graduate entry and a re-registration scheme to ensure that social workers were continually developing their knowledge and skills. "Let's hold our heads up. Like the doctors, we should take responsibility for refreshing our skills."

The current, two-year social work qualification is not enough to prepare staff for their first job and standards vary too much among institutions, Williams believes. "But if we are going to make it three years, we have to be clearer about the skills and aptitudes that we need as employers. There will be fewer social workers, but they will be more skilled and better paid."

John Ransford, head of social care at the Local Government Association, says employers will have to think more carefully about how a new intermediate grade might be created. It will be important to give people the service they expect without de-skilling or exploiting staff. "We will work with government, rather than against it, to work out the detail."
