Hutton says: "With up to 1.5m people relying on social services in England, we must have a system which is robust and of the highest quality... This strategy offers anyone who cares about social services a real opportunity to make radical changes. It must be grasped." Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, says the profession should welcome graduate entry and a re-registration scheme to ensure that social workers were continually developing their knowledge and skills. "Let's hold our heads up. Like the doctors, we should take responsibility for refreshing our skills." The current, two-year social work qualification is not enough to prepare staff for their first job and standards vary too much among institutions, Williams believes. "But if we are going to make it three years, we have to be clearer about the skills and aptitudes that we need as employers. There will be fewer social workers, but they will be more skilled and better paid." John Ransford, head of social care at the Local Government Association, says employers will have to think more carefully about how a new intermediate grade might be created. It will be important to give people the service they expect without de-skilling or exploiting staff. "We will work with government, rather than against it, to work out the detail."  A Quality Strategy for Social Care paper The JM Consulting report

webTitle: The Smithers-Robinson index: interpretation and methodology

fields.headline: The Smithers-Robinson index: interpretation and methodology
fields.trailText: Universities and Colleges
fields.byline: Professor Alan Smithers and Dr Pamela Robinson, University of Liverpool
fields.body:
Universities and Colleges

This is the second year we have produced the league tables in this form. They again show wide variation between the leading providers and those making up the rear. At the head of the list is Oxford which has excellent Ofsted inspection grades and some 70 per cent of the intake have good degrees. Homerton College is second and the University of East Anglia third just in front of Cambridge University. From the bottom up the order is Huddersfield, North London, Open and East London.

The table brings out the huge variation in the entry qualifications between the training providers. At the top are institutions with intakes where more than half have a good degree for PGCE courses or 20+ A-level points (equivalent to B plus 2 Cs) for undergraduate courses. At the bottom are those where only a handful have reached these levels. The figures relate to 1998 where the overall secondary intake reached only 75 per cent of target, and evidently some providers have struggled to fill their places.

There is less variation in inspection grades and employment. The variation in inspection grades tends to mirror that for the quality of intake, but a minimum standard has to be reached for compliance. Schools are desperately short of teachers and have been taking newly qualified staff irrespective of entry qualifications or the rating of the provider. The low position of the Open University is, however, due mainly to the high drop- out from its courses during the year leading to low employment figures.

The universities and colleges table is similar to that for last year. Seven of the top ten are the same. Sussex (6 from 15), Leicester (7 from 12) and Warwick (10 from 13) come in for Bishop Grosseteste (4 to 15), Bristol (7 to 17) and York (9 to 12). Seven of the bottom ten are also the same. The changers are dropping in East London (23 down to 74), Newman (54 down to 71) and Greenwich (66 to 68). Moving out are Leeds Met (77 to 47), Portsmouth (75 to 41) and South Bank (69 to 60).

Although the overall pattern is one of relative stability there are some major moves.

East London*s big drop is due mainly to none of the intake being shown as having a good degree. Since last year the figure was 45 per cent one suspects that one or the other return may not be correct but both were signed off by the institution. The other big fallers were Nottingham (18 to 45), Anglia Polytechnic (33 to 61), De Montfort (42 to 64) and Bath Spa (43 to 65). These were due mainly to a fall in the qualifications of the intake though Anglia's inspection grades also fell.

Those taking the biggest strides up the table were Hull (63 to 21), Portsmouth (75 to 41), Trinity and All Saints (64 to 31), Leeds Met (77 bottom to 47) and Manchester (52 to 25). There progress was mainly due to a steep rise in entry qualifications and also in proportions taking employment is schools. Leeds Metropolitan's primary inspection ratings also improved.

Although there were these movers the average scores changed little between the years. Average intake scores were up slightly for both primary (78.5 to 79.5) and secondary (82.9 to 83.5) suggesting some small improvement in the quality of recruits. Employment of the secondary trainees was also up (from 134.6 to 138.7), but averages for employment primary and the inspection grades were about the same.

The universities and colleges table does not include three institutions which offer only one secondary course - Staffordshire University (economics), Central School of Speech and Drama (Drama) and Maryvale Institute (religious education). If they had been included Staffordshire (910.8) would have been third, and Maryvale (849.2) and CSSP (846.0) would have been in the top ten.

School Based Schemes

The number of school-based schemes is increasing. This year's table includes 22 providers compared with 18 last year, as a result of five more having run long enough for full data to be available and one existing SCITT (West Midlands) being excluded because it offers only one course (PE). Another seven lack full inspection grades, there are six new starters in 99- 00 and 14 scheduled for 2000-01, making 50 in all. However the total number of trainees is small with each provider offering only about twenty places. The total of 719 trainees (323 primary and 396 secondary) in 1998-99 would put all the SCITTs together behind Manchester Met (1216), Open University (910), St Martin*s (898), London Institute of Education (874) and De Montfort (750) as training providers. Nevertheless there is a continuing shift to the school-based route.

On average the entry qualifications to the primary SCITT schemes tend to be higher (94.7 against 79.5) as do the employment figures (163.4 against 146.7), but the inspection grades appreciably lower (98.1 against 134.9). For the secondary SCITTs entry grades are lower (66.6 against 87.0), but the inspection grades (103.9 and 99.5) and employment figures (138.1 and 141.4) are not very different.

Because the individual numbers are small there is more variability in the SCITT table than there is in that for the Universities and Colleges. Compared with last year the Wandsworth Schools* Consortium climbs from 8th to 1st and North Bedfordshire Consortium from 9th to 2nd. But Mid Essex falls from 7th to 14th and Gloucestershire ITE from 3rd to 19th. Wandsworth*s rise is mainly associated with greatly improved inspection ratings (though no SCITT has yet achieved an A). Gloucester's fall is mainly due to much lower entry qualifications and employment figures. Billericay last year's leader dropped to fourth because it accepted on lower entry qualifications this year.

If instead of separating the universities and colleges from the SCITTS they were included in the one table (as in Table 1), three of the school-based schemes would be in the top ten, Wandsworth (3rd) and North Bedfordshire (4th) above Cambridge University, and the Oxfordshire Consortium (8th). But six of the last ten places would be occupied by SCITTs, including the bottom five. There is thus considerable variation in the school-based provision compared to the established training institutions.

Methods

The league tables are derived from The Initial Teacher Training Profiles 2000 published by the Teacher Training Agency on 30 August 2000. The data have been collected by the TTA and signed off as accurate by the providers. They refer to the year 1998-99 so that employment and intake figures for PGCE course can be for the same people.

The maximum score is 1200 arrived at from maxima of 200 each for entry qualifications, Ofsted inspection grades, and employment as teachers, for both primary and secondary. Where the provider offers only primary or secondary the scores for the three areas are doubled to give the same overall maximum score.

fields.headline: Letsbuyit.com announces job losses
fields.trailText: One-fifth of staff at the internet retailer Letsbuyit.com are to be shed in an effort to streamline costs, despite an 82% surge in sales this quarter.
fields.body:
One-fifth of staff at the internet retailer Letsbuyit.com are to be shed in an effort to streamline costs, despite an 82% surge in sales this quarter.

The UK-based retailer today announced 80 job losses from its 400-strong staff, mainly from the ranks of temporary staff and advisers.

Letsbuyit, which pools together customers to bargain for lower prices from manufacturers of consumer goods, will remain heavily loss-making until 2003, according to analysts.

The e-commerce company's second-quarter sales have jumped to £4.4m, with its gross margin rising to 9.8% from 2.9%.

The reorganisation will centralise Letsbuyit's European procurement, logistics and marketing activities and lead to one-off costs totalling £920,000 in the third quarter.

Traders are cautious about the second-quarter sales rise. "It's basically a base effect - in general an investment in Letsbuyit remains a high-risk one because they've said they'll break even relatively far in the future," said Edward Martens, a trader at MM Warburg in Hamburg.

Letsbuyit stock has tumbled 40% from its peak in July as technology investors worldwide preferred software and internet infrastructure companies over loss-making e-commerce enterprises.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: Every team that has won the World Cup has a star somewhere on their shirt to represent the number of times they have won. This was evident in France's strip for Euro 2000, where a single star appeared above their badge. Where is the star on England's shirt? Is this due to England winning the old Jules Rimet trophy and France, Italy Brazil et al winning the modern version? I have also seen these stars on the Juventus and AC Milan shirts - anyone know why this is? asks Paul Worrall
fields.body:
Every team that has won the World Cup has a star somewhere on their shirt to represent the number of times they have won. This was evident in France's strip for Euro 2000, where a single star appeared above their badge. Where is the star on England's shirt? Is this due to England winning the old Jules Rimet trophy and France, Italy Brazil et al winning the modern version? I have also seen these stars on the Juventus and AC Milan shirts - anyone know why this is? asks Paul Worrall

Countries who have won the World Cup are indeed entitled to wear one star on their shirts for each of their victories. But the lack of a star on the England shirt is nothing to do with the fact they won the Jules Rimet trophy instead of the current pot - Uruguay, champions in 1930 and 1950, wear stars above their crest, after all.

No, the reason England's shirts are star free is because the FA consider the three lions to be a "historically recognisable emblem in iteslf" and see no need to "muck about with embellishments", to quote spokesperson David Barber.

Meanwhile, the gold stars on Italian shirts you refer to are awarded to clubs who have won the Italian championship ten times. Milan, for example, have won 13 titles and are entitled to wear one star above their badge; Juventus are the only club with two stars.

Incidentally, if you watch Lazio play this season, you may notice a green, white and red shield on their shirts where their club crest should be. This shield is 'lo scudetto', and is worn all season by the current Italian champions in place of their usual logo. Now, would the brand manager of Manchester United stand for that?

Why did the East German team play in blue? asked James Spackman a few weeks ago.

"The answer almost certainly lies in the fact that the shirts of the East German youth movement, the so-called "Free German Youth (FDJ)" were also blue," says Donald Phillips. "When sport started in post-war East Germany, it was under the auspices of the FDJ," he continues. "The colour of the FDJ shirts was in turn chosen as a neutral response - as opposed to the red-brown shirts of the Hitler youth. The FDJ was, of course, the youth arm of the governing party of East Germany, the Socialist Unity party, formed by the remnants of the pre-Nazi era German Communist Party and SPD."

Donald goes on to say that during one match the head of the Stasi, Erich Mielke, who was watching in the directors' box, was told off by the East German trainer for griping about the referee. "Shut up and sit down," he was told, "you know nothing about football." Mr Mielke, bless his ideological red socks, responded with: "It's a free country, I'm entitled to my opinion."

What is Kanu's squad number for Nigeria? I know his Arsenal number is 25 but I'm sure it's different for internationals reckons Ross Kenny.

You're right Ross. Kanu's Nigerian squad number is 4. Thanks to Ben Ayliffe, Andrew Yiannouzis, the madgooner and everyone who wrote in with the answer.

Is it possible in a normal game for the goalie to swap positions with one of his outfield colleagues, as is the usual practice in park football? asked Mick Kassim last week.

"We (Camborne School of Mines FC) did it in a crucial end-of-season relegation battle at Gwinear in Cornwall Mining League Division 1," says the wonderfully named Dr Varyl Thorndycraft. "The important thing, however, is to let the referee know," he continues. "We swapped at half-time, played for five minutes or so in the 2nd half, then when our new goalie picked up the ball for the first time the ref blew for a penalty, saying he didn't know he was the keeper (despite the fact he was wearing a different colour top and gloves and a cloth cap, etc). But fortunately the penalty was saved!"

Can you help?

After Liverpool's shocking capitulation at the Dell, many critics that the Liverpool of old would never have given away a three-goal lead. Is this true? Did Liverpool ever give away such a lead in a year they went on to win the League? asks Paul Rodriguez

Is it true that John Phillips, who played (I think) for Chelsea in the early 70s played for Wales while his brother represented a different home nation? asks Brent Franklin

My mate says he read in a newspaper (so it must be true!) that Premiership clubs make a charge (something like £50) for the privilege of allowing their children to run out onto the pitch with the players on Saturday afternoons. I can't believe they would be so mercenary (but I'm only young). Does anyone have any information? asks Kim Shiner

If a free kick is advanced 10 yards by the referee into the penalty area does it become a penalty? The answer is of course no, it remains a free kick, but I would like to know what kind of free kick, says Kevin Rainey. I think any free-kick should become indirect on entering the area - am I right?

Continuing the theme on German Football, does anyone know why 1860 Munich are so-named? I'm assuming it's not the year that the club was formed as the older English clubs were only formed around 1890, asks Simon Beresford

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: Mercury rising as rival buys Checkpoint

fields.headline: Mercury rising as rival buys Checkpoint
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: E-commerce payments firm Checkpoint Holdings was yesterday sold to its Nasdaq-listed rival, Bottomline Technologies, for £53m.
fields.body:
E-commerce payments firm Checkpoint Holdings was yesterday sold to its Nasdaq-listed rival, Bottomline Technologies, for £53m.

Checkpoint, based in Reading, was the subject of a £17m management buyout 18 months ago and the sale represents a threefold investment gain for backer Mercury Private Equity.

The company specialises in providing secure payment solutions to businesses and was founded in 1985. It has 3,000 customers, including 95 from the FTSE 100 index of leading British companies.

Bottomline, which is based in Portsmouth, Hampshire, operates in a similar market and was floated on Nasdaq last year. It is also buying a Boston-based software firm called Flashpoint for £9m.

The enlarged Bottomline group will be able to offer electronic invoicing, payment and banking services.

Mercury Private Equity, which was spun out of Merrill Lynch last month, said that a shift in Checkpoint's strategy since the buyout towards more profitable, high growth opportunities had driven the sharp rise in the company's valuation.

The sale comes weeks before Mercury is set to embark on a new fundraising round. It manages more than £1bn in funds. Last year Mercury invested in nine companies with a total valuation in excess of £1.2bn.

fields.headline: The racist poison pill
fields.standfirst:
One whisper from the Tories about 'foreign doctors' is enough to get the toxin into the political system

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: One whisper from the Tories about 'foreign doctors' is enough to get the toxin into the political system.
fields.body:
It floats like a butterfly, stings like a bee, the gentle flutter of a racist sentiment tripping off a politician's lips on gossamer wings. One puff and it's gone, completely deniable. What me? Racist? It works like magic. Everyone gets the message, yet nothing tangible remains. It was a quiet bank holiday with no news beyond the Tory slippage in the polls so into the void stepped Dr Liam Fox, Conservative health spokesman, a clever man.

With great finesse he suggests that foreign doctors "can be fatal", "patients are suffering at their hands" and "this is an issue of patient safety". Images flash before the eyes of his blue-rinse party members - doctors with funny names and weird accents who turn up as locums in the middle of the night "can be fatal"! Every innate suspicion of foreigners, every atavistic fear of otherness is nicely stirred. Peter Sellers' comic Indian doctor with his "needle in the Punjab" is the kind of joke they still really enjoy. So Dr Fox's comments do the political business. The clear message goes out - the Tories will bring back Doctor Finlay, no more darkies on the wards.

Of course he never said that but the joy of race is that it only has to be breathed. So he said the Tories would bring in tougher language tests and tougher medical exams for all foreign doctors, including those already practising. With no evidence, no research and apparently zero knowledge of how the system works, his cavalier assault on the quarter of doctors now working in the NHS who trained elsewhere was insulting and unpleasant. Fox concentrated his remarks on what he claimed was their poor language skills, saying: "In potential life-and-death situations having a minimal standard of proficiency in English can be fatal." He just threw in the need to toughen the medical exams as an apparent afterthought. But it planted the idea - voodoo third world stuff, jungle doctors, jungle medicine.

Naturally he has vehemently denied racism. He would, wouldn't he? But why on earth did he choose to bring up such a minor issue among the plethora of NHS inadequacies for which there are good figures and damning evidence, instead of just gut prejudice? He had a point about the lack of language tests for EU doctors working here - but did he really mean the fatal threat of a Frenchman?

What's the best evidence available? Rather more complaints about foreign-trained doctors are received by the General Medical Council sent in by other public bodies in relation to the number there are practising, but then rather fewer complaints against overseas doctors are sent in by the general public. There is no evidence that patients try to change doctors to avoid foreigners. In a specialism with an acute shortage, Professor John Lilleyman, president of the Royal College of Pathologists, dismissed Dr Fox's remarks. "Thirty years ago some doctors could barely string two words of English together, but it's all changed now. There is a shortage of pathologists, with 100 consultant jobs unfilled: Wigan district general has one part-timer instead of three full-timers, putting cancer and other diagnoses at risk.

Professor John Cox, president of the Royal College of Psychiatry, says that Dr Fox has no evidence. "He is casting a slur on overseas doctors. We find British doctors are just as likely to have communication problems with patients. Hardly surprising since it requires doctors who have specialised for years to relearn the whole medical syllabus from when they first qualified.

The real scandal is not incompetent foreigners killing NHS patients, it is the estimated 2,000 refugee doctors, many of them distinguished, who cannot work here. Dr Sheila Cheeroth runs the Refugee Doctor Project at Queen Mary and Westfield College, London. The barriers set up against them are near impossible. She mentions a Somalian who worked as an Assistant Professor of Obstetrics and Gynaecology in Russia, headed the Red Crescent in Somalia during the famine, worked at WHO headquarters in Geneva and speaks five languages. But he can't find medical work.

It costs the NHS £200,000 to train a new doctor. Dr Cheeroth says most of these refugees could be retrained, some for as little as £1,000, most others for £10,000. But those who arrive without money have virtually no chance, however distinguished their experience. To take the PLAB exam costs £550. To take a short PLAB revision course costs £625. The IELTS language courses are expensive too. Then doctors need two clinical attachments, lasting about three months each, working alongside an NHS doctor: these are not only unpaid but applicants have to pay £500 each time, while trying to supporting their families. Research published in the BMJ tested racism in medicine by sending out applications for jobs in a variety of specialisms, half with an Asian name, half with an English-sounding name. The Asian names were far less likely to be shortlisted.

Asylum seekers are not allowed to work in their first six months, dispersed randomly around the country living on vouchers, with no money for bus fares let alone training courses. After that, the DSS pressures them to take jobs, often cleaning jobs, which makes it even harder for them to study and pass exams. Doctors who become refugees are among the most educated and sophisticated people who arrive here. Although the Refugee Council and others offer what courses they can, only 20% of refugee doctors ever practice medicine again. The scandal is the waste.

Dr Fox was not replying to his pager yesterday. Why should he? One dab of the tar brush is all it takes.

fields.headline: Travellers win race ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Irish travellers are a separate ethnic group entitled to the same protection under the Race Relations Act as other ethnic minorities in Britain, a court ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
Irish travellers are a separate ethnic group entitled to the same protection under the Race Relations Act as other ethnic minorities in Britain, a court ruled yesterday.

The decision was taken by a judge presiding over the case of eight travellers, who are claiming racial discrimination against five London pubs they say refused to serve them because of their ethnic origin.

Lawyers for Punch Retail, owners of three of the pubs, argued that the travellerswere not covered by the Race Relations Act so could not bring the case. But Judge Goldstein rejected the claims at a pre liminary hearing at Central London county court yesterday, saying Irish travellers had a shared history stretching back to the mid 19th century and should be given protection as an "ethnic group".

"Modern Irish travellers are guided by the culture and traditions which have been handed down by generations. They do not go around reading history, they practise it."

He said that to exclude Irish travellers from protection under the Race Relations Act would leave three glaring anomalies - the appeal court had decided Romany Gypsies were covered by the legislation and the two groups shared many characteristics; it would fly in the face of the broad provisions against discrimination provided by the European convention on human rights and the group already enjoyed protection in Ulster under the Northern Ireland Race Relations Order.

Four of the travellers, Patrick O'Leary and Michael, Margaret and Kathleen Kiely, were in court to hear the verdict, and said in a statement: "We hope this success will encourage other Irish travellers to use the law whenever they are discriminated against."

The travellers claim they were refused service in April 1998. Punch Retail was given 42 days to lodge an appeal before a trial date is set.

webTitle: Comment: All the world's an advert

fields.headline: All the world's an advert
fields.standfirst: Every possible space is used to flog stuff. Now, about my new book ...
fields.trailText: Every possible space is used to flog stuff. Now, about my new book...
fields.body:
Wordsworth's famous lines will soon need to be updated. "I wandered lonely as a cloud, That floats on high o'er hill and dale, When all at once I saw a huge billboard telling me to fcuk fashion." The government has announced that advertising hoardings will now be permitted across most of the English countryside. Clearly the millions of visitors to our shores this summer were disappointed that the views across rural England were not obscured by enormous posters and so the government have stepped in to put this right.

The abolition of controls originally brought in under the Atlee government follow intensive lobbying from that great lover of our natural heritage, the Outdoor Advertising Council. We are assured that we will still see beautiful scenery in the English countryside, but only as featured on the poster advertising the new Vauxhall Astra.

Now the chit-chat on The Archers will be changed forever. "Ooh I've got terrible problems; no rain for a month, winter cabbage gone to seed and the focus group has revealed that the branding concept on my poster sites is failing to reach the targeted C2s." Once farmers have got the advertising bug they might find other ways to get the message across. The sheep in One Man and His Dog won't just be herded into a pen; the collies will have to arrange them on the hillside to spell out: "You can't get kwikker than a kwik-fit fitter". Bright yellow mustard will be planted in such a formation that airline passengers flying overhead will see the Nike logo. Bored looking cows will stand around in fields holding placards that say "Massive golf sale - 100 yards on the left".

There are always more places in which commercials can be placed. Soon it won't be possible to have a hearing aid fitted that doesn't contain a tape that privately plays you the Shake'n'Vac jingle every five minutes. Or what about advertising during the Queens Christmas message? "At this festive time one's thoughts turn to the Commonwealth, but also to the fact that the World of Leather sale starts 9am Boxing Day at Lakeside Thurrock, Bluewater and Purley Way, Croydon."

The trouble is, of course, that the more advertisements to which we are exposed, the less effective they become. The first piece of junk mail was probably read quite carefully. John Prescott giving permission to increase the number of poster sites won't result in a corresponding rise in consumption of all the products advertised. We are still only going to buy one car each, John Prescott excepted. Advertising might persuade us to switch from Coca Cola to Pepsi but it won't make us spend money we haven't got on things we don't want. However many times I watch the videos standing in the post office queue, I am still no nearer to buying myself a Stannah stairlift.

And yet the advertisers continue their stampede towards devaluing their own currency. I had a drink in a pub in Barnes the other day which featured a TV screen on the wall permanently playing advertisements. As far as I'm concerned this is the end of all civilisation as we know it. I don't know how much Young's brewery or the landlord receive for having this monstrosity ruin the pub, but if The Bulls Head were my local I'd like to try and help raise the same amount to have it taken down again.

The proliferation in advertising is steadily eating away our quality of life and is becoming increasingly ineffective as it does so. And the idea that the financial crisis facing British farming can be solved with roadside posters is clearly ridiculous. The farmers in greatest need live in the remotest areas and have no sites of any value. It is true that that the more accessible areas of rural England do receive thousands of visitors every year but it is precisely because they are unspoilt. The act of erecting poster sites will in itself help make the sites valueless. Somehow I can't imagine myself driving down to Somerset to look at the view of Chris Eubank sipping a mug of Nescafe.

The way forward is to combine two countryside problems to create an overall solution. While it is rightly banning fox hunting the government should add an amendment legalising the hunting of advertising executives. Yuppie account handlers will be strolling around the countryside checking out their new advertising hoardings when suddenly the horn will sound and packs of hounds will descend upon them snapping at their Armani suits as red-coated huntsmen gallop across the fields in pursuit. It will become one of the beautiful traditional sights of the English countryside. It's a shame that the billboards will prevent anyone from actually seeing it.

And until then we must halt this mercenary tendency to use every imaginable space to try and flog people things.

John O'Farrell's new novel, The Best A Man Can Get, is published by Doubleday on October 6

webTitle: 23 injured as Paris metro train derails

fields.headline: 23 injured as Paris metro train derails
fields.standfirst:
RATP
Paris metro map
France Info radio
fields.trailText: 23 passengers were injured this afternoon when a metro train in northern Paris derailed and partially flipped over, just missing another underground train standing on the opposite track, French emergency services said.
fields.body:
23 passengers were injured this afternoon when a metro train in northern Paris derailed and partially flipped over, just missing another underground train standing on the opposite track, French emergency services said.

The train was travelling at 22 mph when it derailed as it entered the Notre-Dame-de-Lorette station in northern Paris.

The victims suffered minor injuries, including cuts, scrapes and bruises. Contrary to earlier reports, no one was seriously injured. One person suffered a broken leg.

Emergency medical officials set up first-aid stations directly on the platform, with others posted outside, as some 170 firefighters in 40 rescue vehicles rushed to the scene of the accident at the station at the foot of the Montmartre hill.

Evangelos Tzonis, 50, told reporters he was in a Metro train on the opposite tracks from the one in involved in the accident. He said the train he was riding was jolted and then the "the entire station was plunged into darkness."

"About a dozen people covered in blood were climbing out of the broken windows," he said. "There was no panic but lots of people were crying."

Alain Caire, the technical director of the Paris transit authority RATP, said officials were seeking the cause of the accident. He said it did not appear that excessive speed was the cause, but said there was some suspicion that an object may have been on the tracks.

Paris police chief Philipe Massoni told reporters at the scene the accident could have turned into a disaster if the derailed train had careered on into a collision.

"We could have had a very serious accident. The engine fell on its side and did not run its full course. This is a miracle," he said.

The Paris underground system, which recently celebrated its 100th anniversary, has a very good safety record, with some four million passengers travelliong on the Metro each day.

webTitle: Crossroads returns in £20m ITV drama push

fields.headline: Crossroads returns in £20m ITV drama push
fields.trailText: ITV has unveiled its biggest drama commission for many years, placing a £20m order for Carlton's Crossroads revival and United Productions' Trafalgar Road.
fields.body:
ITV has unveiled its biggest drama commission for many years, placing a £20m order for Carlton's Crossroads revival and United Productions' Trafalgar Road.

Crossroads, the epitome of cheesy 1970s TV, is to return in a daytime slot, while Trafalgar Road will replace the Channel 5-bound Home and Away in ITV's early evening schedule. Both soaps have budgets of around £10m. They have been commissioned initially for a 12-month run and will be broadcast daily from early next year.

The new soap orders follow a lengthy commissioning process that saw six proposals vying to replace the Australian show. That Crossroads missed out on this slot but still secured a daytime commission is a major coup for the managing director of Carlton Productions, Waheed Alli, who lobbied hard for the revival.

The new Crossroads will still be set just outside Birmingham, but the motel with the shaky walls is to be upgraded to a hotel - The Kings Oak - with a bar, restaurant, conference centre and beauty salon. The original ran for 24 years from 1964 until 1988.

Casting for the new version is due to begin in October. The production team will be based at Carlton's Nottingham centre and the drama is to be shot in the studio and on location. The project has been led by Carlton controller of drama Jonathan Powell.

ITV controller of daytime Maureen Duffy said: "The new Crossroads will be absolutely of our time. It will strengthen ITV's daytime schedule by providing our viewers with strong narrative dealing with the realities, issues and fun of everyday life."

Trafalgar Road will be set in south-east London and centres around a group of friends "watching their children grow up when they haven't finished growing up themselves", according to a United spokeswoman. "It's about parents wishing they were still teenagers and struggling to make sense of their lives. They have teenage kids who think they know everything."

The executive producers are United Productions controller of drama Michele Buck and Damien Timmer. Trafalgar Road has been created by Caleb Ranson, whose writing credits include ITV dramas Forgotten and Daylight Robbery.

Trafalgar Road and Crossroads won through against Richfield, from Hewland International; Shed Productions' Big City; and two Yorkshire Television projects, Hope Point and Big Smoke.

fields.headline: Slitting, Slagging and Spraying
fields.trailText: GERS GEE UP GLOOMY FANS
fields.body:
GERS GEE UP GLOOMY FANS

What do you do when your closest and most bitter rivals totally wallop you 6-2? You could slit your wrists. Or stick pins in an effigy of Chris Sutton. Or chuck all your official merchandise (replica shirt, novelty bowler hat, musical sash, etc.) onto the fire and swear never to march anywhere near Edmiston Drive again. But what would that achieve? Nothing positive, that's for sure. A much more level-headed response would be to breathe deeply, sit down, and quietly wait for your morale to be boosted by some good news.

If you did, suicidal Rangers fans, you've been rewarded for your good sense. Because today Dick Advocaat agreed to buy Ronald De Boer from Barcelona for £6m, the Dutch midfielder agreeing personal terms on a four-year contract. De Boer announced the move on his official website www.icons.com, and next to a huge and frankly scary picture of his head, he wrote: "I'm about to undergo a medical, which is always a little bit nerve-wracking, but I've been fairly injury-free so everything should be okay on that score. I'm already looking forward to linking up with my new team-mates."

That's great news guaranteed to cheer up even the bluest bluenose. And the rehabilitation didn't stop there, because Rangers announced that they are also having talks with Wimbledon striker John Hartson. The 25-year-old's agent is believed to be on his way to Glasgow to seal a £7m deal, and the big Welsh loon could be unveiled later today. Now, the Fiver is usually totally impartial in these matters, but we really hope Hartson's signing goes through. Why? Well, picture the next Old Firm game... Big John up front... the crowd whipping him up into a frenzy... and who's that wily Israeli midfielder lining up for the other team?

THE LATEST FROM DECAMPED DESCHAMPS

It's not often the Fiver ambles up to Frank Leboeuf and mumbles the most difficult word of all: sorry. But, as history will record, today is such a day. Well, sort of. Because a couple of weeks ago, when the arrogant Frenchman claimed that Vialli "has problems with everybody", we took "everybody" to mean Albert Ferrer and Leboeuf's rather large ego. How wrong we were. Today, Didier Deschamps became the third person in recent months to have a pop at Luca, who he blamed for his poor season at Chelsea.

"In England I had difficulty showing my qualities," he moaned for about the 1415th time. "I arrived from Italy with techniques which were useless in England [insert your own joke here], there were too many games and no break in December." But it was loveable Luca who caused Didi the most problems. "I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became." Unresolved issues, anyone?

Before the Fiver could direct Didier to Dr Raj Persaud's home page, the mini-sized midfield general went on to echo He Is He Was's comments about the underlying racism in English football: "A foreigner is less protected than a British player. It's a paradox because there are very good English referees who can perform very well in a European game but are too fussy or too lax in the Premier League. No one really complains about it - neither the public nor the media - and I'm not here to tell them they are wrong." Of course you're not Didi, but we get the message all the same.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I am not here to defend them. I know what they're feeling. But let's put it all in perspective. They haven't murdered anybody, no one has been raped and no drugs have been sold. They made a mistake. But I have made more mistakes than anyone" - Roy Keane QC cleverly juxtaposes different crimes to defend Irish team-mates Phil Starsky and Mark Hutch.

PHYSIO REPORT

[Bounce, bounce, bounce] What's that noise ? Why... it's little Tony Adams! Hello mate. You want to tell us about your ambitions for the England team? OK, before you do, pelt this football at that boring bald bloke's head, will you? [Tok] Nice one! Now, what did you want to say? "Obviously when you don't get success, then people maybe perceive you as not being very good. We need to get out there and get a little bit more respect back, that's certainly what I'm going for." Sorry to interrupt... chuck us that deodorant, will you?

[Fling] Thanks! You were saying? "I didn't think we played particularly well against the Germans, to be honest with you. I watched that game and I was very disappointed with the way we passed the ball. Sometimes it can disguise what's going on under the surface and put a few plasters on the cracks, so it will be more the manner of the performance in Paris which matters." Coming down the pub for an orange juice, Tone? Got to meet the girlfriend.

[Tug, tug, tug] Tony! It's hard enough to catch the barman's eye without you pulling away at the leg of our trousers! Behave yourself and tell us how you think Alan Shearer's retirement will affect the way England play. "When you've got a dominant centre-forward like Alan, you kind of get stuck in a role that you want to play. Certain individuals do influence the way that you play." So do you think England could become a better with a new Shearer-free attacking approach? "Hopefully. That's what I'm aiming for." We wish you luck, Tone, and... hey, is that little bloke in cricket whites waving at you?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds are preparing a move for Hertha Berlin striker Ali Daei, according to Teamtalk. They quote a source close to the German club who says: "Leeds would be ready to buy Daei and Hertha would not hesitate in selling."

Teamtalk also claims that Sunderland are about to table an £8m bid for Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu.

NEWS IN BRIEF

West Brom are to sign Tottenham winger Ruel Fox for £200,000. Fox, who initially moved to Albion on loan so he could play in the Bank Holiday games, said: "Everything has been sorted out. I will be signing a two-year contract."

Steve Claridge has signed a new three-year contract with Portsmouth, which will keep the striker at the club until he is 37.

Norwich midfielder Chris Llewellyn has undergone an operation after suffering a fractured cheekbone in Monday's 1-0 defeat against Fulham. He is likely to be out for at least a couple of months.

Lyon have signed Brazilian defender Edmilson - a former target of Arsenal - from Sao Paulo for £7m.

Diego Maradona has denied he is making a comeback after reports yesterday suggested he had provisionally signed for Argentine second division side All Boys. "All Boys? No, I have nothing to do with them at all," he said. "My future plans are the same as I said in July, which are staying here and continuing with my treatment. I am very happy in Cuba and I will stay in Cuba."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.25am)

The title looks a bit like Football Pizza if you squint really hard.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am)

Last night seemed to be one very long advert for Rodney Marsh's new website (www.rodmarsh.com). But when are they going to launch www.mccaff.co.uk? That's what we want to know!

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (11.30pm, 1.30 SS1)

Balls all over the place.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Games rendered in words and transmitted using the latest in electricity-based technology.

Midweek 6-0-6 (10pm)

fields.headline: Time for a transfer merry-go-round
fields.trailText: Cricket's transfer market tends to be as busy as a butcher's on Boxing Day, although Chris Lewis and Phil DeFreitas have been known to boost business. In some respects this is a good thing: county followers can forge emotional bonds with their favourite players and may even wish them well if they do finally join another side (football fans treat former heroes who have moved on with more animosity than they treat each other). In other respects it is a shame, because this sort of idle speculation rarely gets put into practice. But, hey, this shouldn't stop us speculating. Because for every Marcus Trescothick and Jason Brown who has broken from the ranks, there are others who have faded into the background. A change of county might be just the answer.
fields.body:
Cricket's transfer market tends to be as busy as a butcher's on Boxing Day, although Chris Lewis and Phil DeFreitas have been known to boost business. In some respects this is a good thing: county followers can forge emotional bonds with their favourite players and may even wish them well if they do finally join another side (football fans treat former heroes who have moved on with more animosity than they treat each other). In other respects it is a shame, because this sort of idle speculation rarely gets put into practice. But, hey, this shouldn't stop us speculating. Because for every Marcus Trescothick and Jason Brown who has broken from the ranks, there are others who have faded into the background. A change of county might be just the answer.

Top of the shopping list is Ben Hollioake. Three years ago, after driving Glenn McGrath to distraction by playing, missing and thumping his way to 63 off 48 balls in a one-day international at Lord's, he was hailed as the new saviour of English cricket. Now he is an increasingly marginal figure at Surrey. When he bowls, he looks like a one-man band trying to outplay the on-song duos of Martin Bicknell and Alex Tudor, Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury. When he bats, he just looks like Saqlain Mushtaq.

He has lost his way, but given more responsibility and careful man-management he can return. Edgbaston may be the place to go. It's a Test ground (somehow you can't imagine Hollioake strutting his stuff at Derby or Colwyn Bay), it's always accommodated allrounders, and it's got Bob Woolmer at the helm, a man who knows a bit about sports psychology. And assuming Adam stays put at The Oval, Ben wouldn't feel as if Big Brother was always watching.

Owais Shah of Middlesex is another young cricketer who has never quite fulfilled his potential. And with Mark Ramprakash out of the England reckoning for the time being, Shah may find first-team opportunities in 2001 as limited as they have been in the last month. Shah needs to find a county with slots to fill in the top-order. Derbyshire's batting has been pitiful this year, but then so have their pitches. An even better choice would be Leicestershire - who will surely dispense with the services of Trevor Ward sooner rather than later - or Nottinghamshire, where the OAPs' garden party is crying out to be crashed.

One player who will definitely be on the move at the end of the summer is Devon Malcolm, who is currently tearing his hair out in Northamptonshire's second XI. He's 37, but by his own reckoning is still fit enough to play county cricket. A trip to Canterbury, where the new-ball attack of David Masters and Martin Saggers has been short of penetration this season, might suit him. Kent have already approached Northants this season about the possibility of borrowing Dev on loan but were turned down. Another attempt would surely be more successful.

Some of England's young bowlers, too, might find that pastures are greener elsewhere, although if they get any greener at Headingley, Matthew Hoggard will simply have to trundle in at 65mph, place the ball on the seam and watch the five-fors roll in. Hoggard is already flattered by Headingley: his 19 Championship wickets there this season have cost 22.58 apiece, while the 16 he has picked up at other grounds have come at an average of 31.06. If England really do believe he is a potential first-change bowler of the future, they should insist he leave Yorkshire and learn to bowl on wickets that make him work harder for success - like Taunton, Northampton, or Hove.

The same goes for Paul Franks of Nottinghamshire and Steve Harmison of Durham: Trent Bridge and Chester-le-Street may make a seamer feel good, but the feel-good factor will soon disappear in a Test match at Lahore or Adelaide.

Wicketkeeper Rob Turner may find his career prospects enhanced by leaving Somerset. Last year he was tipped as a future England player; this year he has faded badly. What about moving to Headingley, where Richard Blakey's powers are on the wane and the seaming ball would provide plenty of opportunity to practise his catching? Yorkshire are also a high-profile county, and although this should have nothing to do with selection, it invariably seems to.

Of course, not all of these questions would arise if all the groundsmen were contracted to the ECB and the pitches were the same throughout the country. England may not yet be able to say who should play for which county, but they can certainly make the debate less relevant - and help their own cause - by getting the pitches in order. But rather like this sort of column, that, for the moment, must remain a dream.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read last week's County View, on how the climax to the first division looks set to be a cracker, click here.

webTitle: Microsoft gears up for launch of .net strategy

fields.headline: Microsoft gears up for launch of .net strategy
fields.trailText: Microsoft is gearing up for the launch of its most strategic evolution to date - its Microsoft.net strategy.
fields.body:
Microsoft is gearing up for the launch of its most strategic evolution to date - its Microsoft.net strategy.

To deliver this strategy to the UK and Irish markets, Microsoft has set up the Strategic Business Development (SBD) Group, which will take a more progressive stance on mobile and broadband technologies than its US counterpart.

The model, not dissimilar to that provided by a dot.com incubator, is part of the company's ambition to develop a network of Microsoft-endorsed service companies that can provide "cradle-to-grave services" for start-ups.

Jeremy Gittins, group marketing manager of SBD, is currently charged with building up a community of third-party suppliers and partnerships that will enable Microsoft to - in Gittins words - "create a self-reliant industry".

The types of companies expected to be involved in this 'community' include venture capitalists, web development agencies, lawyers and marketers. One such partnership, which suggests Microsoft is earnest about being in the mobile space, is an alliance with BT to develop wireless products. Nothing has yet been confirmed but it is expected that Microsoft will announce this, and other partnerships, at the end of September when it launches Microsoft.net.

The idea behind the community is that Microsoft remains behind the scenes and merely provides network links and the infrastructure needed to help businesses go forward, with the main emphasis on mobility and internet distribution of applications.

"Microsoft.net is the biggest thing we've ever done and it's our next milestone as a company. We're focusing on four main areas: dot.coms, application service provision (ASP) and mobility and mega-services (such as useful tools like Passport.com). The partnerships are fundamental to this. We know conceptually what we want to do, but it's going to be a lot of hard work," said Gittins.

webTitle: ITV commissions a new soap for 2001: Crossroads

fields.headline: ITV commissions a new soap for 2001: Crossroads
fields.standfirst: Twelve years after it was taken off air, the epitome of cheesy 70s television is being updated to return to our screens. But will Benny be back, asks Jason Deans
fields.trailText:
Wednesday, 4.30pm:
Twelve years after it was taken off air, the epitome of cheesy 70s television is being updated to return to our screens. But will Benny be back, asks Jason Deans
fields.body:
For fans of Benny and Miss Diane, the 12-year wait is over. Crossroads, the epitome of cheesy 1970s television, is returning to ITV as a daily daytime soap early next year.

The new Crossroads will still be set just outside Birmingham, but the motel with the shaky walls is to be upgraded to a hotel - the Kings Oak - with a bar, restaurant, conference centre and beauty salon.

ITV and producer Carlton are not revealing whether Benny and other characters from the original Crossroads will be returning, along with the dodgy scripts and production values and the distinctive theme tune.

Casting is to begin in October and further details about the soap are expected nearer transmission. The production team for the 21st-century Crossroads will be based at Carlton's Nottingham centre and the drama is to be shot in the studio and on location.

ITV's controller of daytime television, Maureen Duffy, said: "The new Crossroads will be absolutely of our time. It really will strengthen ITV's daytime schedule by providing our viewers with strong narrative dealing with the realities, issues and fun of everyday life."

The commercial broadcaster has ordered a 12-month, five-day-a-week run of Crossroads. A second daily drama, United Productions' Trafalgar Road, has been commissioned to replace the early evening Australian soap Home and Away, which has been poached by Channel 5.

Trafalgar Road will be set in south-east London and focuses on a group of friends "watching their children grow up when they haven't finished growing up themselves", according to a United spokeswoman. She added: "It's about parents wishing they were still teenagers and struggling to make sense of their lives. They have teenage kids who think they know everything."

The original Crossroads ran for 24 years, from 1964 until 1988. Noele Gordon, who played the motel's matriarchal owner Meg, was voted favourite female personality in the TV Times awards seven years in a row during the show's 70s heyday.

When Gordon was written out of Crossroads in 1981 thousands wrote to producer Central Television to complain, and the Sun launched the Save Our Meg campaign.

The 1980s brought a slow, inexorable decline in the soap's ratings, despite several changes of direction aimed at reviving it. A younger, more glamorous actor, Gabrielle Drake, took over the motel in 1985. Two years later the show was rebranded Crossroads, Kings Oak, in a last-ditch attempt to attract a more upmarket following.

fields.headline: We are gathered here again ...
fields.standfirst: Grant Bovey married Anthea Turner last week, watched by his daughters from his first marriage. But, says  Maureen Freely,  the Second Wedding Experience can be traumatic for children
fields.trailText: Grant Bovey married Anthea Turner last week, watched by his daughters from his first marriage. But, says Maureen Freely, the Second Wedding Experience can be traumatic for children.
fields.body:
First he cheats on her. Then he leaves her. Then Grant Bovey decides he's made a terrible mistake running off with Anthea Turner and talks Della into taking him back. But he has not been back long before Della discovers he is still carrying on with Anthea. There's another scene. Grant the Rat scuttles off again. Della resolves to put it all behind her - begin a new life, help her children pick up after this disaster and move on. But she has hardly had a chance to catch her breath before her children are swept off to feature as extras in Grant and Anthea's glitzy wedding.

How did she feel to see her tragedy turned into a celebration? Didn't it hurt even more to know her children would be there to watch? Did she have any qualms about letting them attend, and if so, why didn't she put her foot down? And what was it like for the children? They must have been left feeling very confused.

In this, at least, they have plenty of company. There is, after all, no "right way" to involve children in a second wedding. It used to be something movie stars did, badly. It's only very recently that people have begun to hope that it's something that should be done nicely.

But how? That's still not clear yet. There are so many permutations, after all. It's one thing if the children in question are too little to know what's happening, and quite another if they're teenagers, and something else again if they're already adults. It matters how much time has passed since the divorce, and why the divorce happened, and how the old spouse and the new spouse get along. If I had no problem about my children attending their father's next wedding, it was because I liked the new wife. I would not have wanted to be there, although I do know of women who have gone along with their children to their ex's weddings.

However, I also know a couple who went through a very bitter divorce but still managed to attend each other's second weddings several years later. They claim to be glad to have done so, and say the children are much more comfortable in their new families as a result. They admit there were awkward and painful moments, but it was better, they say, to have an extra pair of parents on hand to keep an eye on the children, who would otherwise have got lost in the throng.

If you want to know how fast children can get lost in a shuffle, all you have to do is talk to adult survivors of the Second Wedding Experience. Here is a good one. A ten-year-old girl picks up the phone to call to her father. It is less than a year since the divorce. After talking at length about his tennis partners and a recent fishing trip, he says: "I'd love to take a boat out when we're in the Bahamas, but it's a foolish man who takes a fishing rod on his honeymoon." This is how she finds out he is getting married that afternoon. When she asks him, "Why didn't you tell me before?" he says, "I don't know, I guess it just slipped my mind."

This girl is now in her 40s but she still flies off the handle when people give her important news "in passing". Would it have been better if her father had written her a formal note? Not necessarily. That's what this girl's mother did. She came home from school one day to find a long satin dress lying on her bed, along with a note saying: "James and I are getting married at two o'clock next Saturday. You are going to be one of the bridesmaids and this is what I want you to wear."

As upset as she was about being left out of her father's second wedding, she was even more upset by being forced to attend her mother's. In neither case, she believed, did the adults show any interest in her feelings - or even consider the idea that her feelings might be important. As far as they were concerned, a wedding was a private agreement between consenting adults.

But traditional weddings have always involved children. They are public events in which the bride and the groom bring all the generations of their families together and formalise their social ties. As the psychologist, Janet Reibstein, points out, it's a ritual that marks the beginning of a new family. To exclude a child from this ritual is to tell her that she does not really belong.

Of course, there are times when a parent truly does not want a child to belong to a new family. Della Bovey might not be particularly keen about the prospect of her children being part of a family that includes Anthea. If she had wanted to undermine this family in its infancy, she could have done so by preventing her children from attending the wedding. If she decided to let them go, it may have been because she thought that keeping them away would hurt the children far more than it could ever hurt their father. Maybe she has heard a story like this: an aggrieved mother bars her four-year-old son from attending his father's second wedding on the grounds that he is "too young". But every time the boy goes to visit his father and his new wife, he gets up at 6am and goes downstairs to watch the wedding video. Because his father refuses to speak against his mother, the boy still thinks he wasn't at the wedding because he wasn't wanted.

Does this mean that children are better off attending second weddings? Not always. Horror stories I know include a five-year-old girl who did not make it to her father's wedding reception because he "forgot" her outside the registry office, and a seven-year-old boy who spent most of his father's wedding reception getting beaten up by his new step-brothers. He suffered in silence: another friend's 13-year-old daughter did not. Instead she got very drunk and told her father and everyone else in the room what a bastard he was. Her father later claimed that her mother had put her up to it. She hadn't, but it is common enough for a child to act up at a second wedding out of loyalty to the parent who "got left behind". Often enough, this parent will be very pleased to hear about it.

But even if all the adults are well-behaved, things can still go wrong. For example, what if the children themselves say they don't want to attend? That's easy, says Reibstein. It probably means they don't want you to get married. They might say it's the shoes you're asking them to wear, or the number of hours they're going to have to sit in a room where they don't know anyone, but it's more likely to be that they don't like the look of the new stepmother, or are afraid that their new stepfather is going to rob them of their mother's affections. So the less time spent arguing about wedding outfits and wedding logistics, says Reibstein, the better the chances of addressing the root causes. And the more the children are involved in the planning of the wedding, the more likely they are to feel all right about it.

Take the long view, she says. Instead of fixating on the day of the actual ceremony, think of the wedding as a ritual that begins months earlier, with the decision to remarry. The point of the ritual is to smooth over raw emotions, to have the new family working as a family by the time the ceremony begins.

But don't get too anxious if you hit a few snags. This advice comes from a boy whose father's car got stuck in a snowdrift when the two of them were driving to the father's second wedding. When the car wouldn't budge, the boy, who was seven, had a crying jag. It was only in early adulthood that he found out his father took this as proof that the boy was deeply traumatised by his parents' divorce, and even more deeply ambivalent about the impending marriage. In fact, the boy was crying because he had a full bladder and was afraid he was going to wet his pants.

The Family Through Divorce: How You Can Limit the Damage by Janet Reibstein and Roger Bamber Thorsons 8.99.

fields.headline: Back-to-school blues
fields.standfirst: Some parents are glad to see the back of the long summer holidays but  Kate Figes  laments the end of the season of silliness and laughter
fields.trailText: Some parents are glad to see the back of the long summer holidays but Kate Figes laments the end of the season of silliness and laughter.
fields.body:
It's back to school next week - so why do I feel so sad? I begin to mourn the loss of each summer even before it's over, as the last days of the holiday seem to signify the end of an entire year rather than just another season. With the first day back at school for the autumn term my children move up a class and gain a year in a matter of moments. There are new teachers and pupils to get to know, tougher rules and new expectations to wrestle with, and the age they were a few weeks ago seems lost forever.

When they are back at school it will be back to that relentless routine - up at seven, off to school at eight, home at four with homework, piano practice, supper and EastEnders before that final heave to get them into bed at a reasonable hour. There is so little time just to be together. Conversations are snatched, there's barely an hour to relax and have fun as a family and we're all so tired that tempers are easily frayed. Sometimes it feels as though we're just four individuals leading separate lives, linked by the same house and the children's immediate needs. I feel like a constant nag getting them through the day; they feel got at and frustrated with too little time to play.

But in summer all that evaporates. My babies are my own again. They sleep in and pad round the house in their pyjamas. They eat more, play more together and fight less. Suddenly, the outside pressures are gone. There is more time for silliness, more space for laughter and their faces soften with rest, fresh air and sunshine. They find new and innovative ways to spend their time - mine spent the first two weeks of this year's holiday swapping bedrooms, a spur-of-the-moment decision made entirely by themselves. As an act of creative upheaval it was superb: it forced them - and us - to clean out their rooms, reassess their possessions, play with old friends and chuck out the broken and the useless.

Summer is the only holiday when nothing much happens. The Christmas break is full of anxiety, too much money spent and family tensions raised to fever pitch. Easter may be a celebration of spring, but it's usually cold and too much chocolate is consumed. Summer, though, is the season when nagging can stop, we can find our equilibrium as a family again with everyone else away and the diary free of social commitment. Holidays in Cornwall, Wales or Suffolk have cemented that sense of family unity even further and created landmark memories - hide and seek in the dark, sea bathing in the rain, marathon sessions of Monopoly.

A child's growth can almost be measured annually by the holiday snaps, which come back just as the shops start their back-to-school promotions. I have more pictures of my daughters in bathing suits eating ice cream on beaches during the summer months than at any other time of year. Each new picture resembles the last - blue sky, yellow sand, green fields and happy, sun-tanned faces. Only the child is slightly different, the younger one losing her curls, her chubby limbs, the elder one slowly developing the physique of a woman, with fuller lips and lengthening limbs. With each new set of photographs there is a sad reminder of how few summers like this there are ahead of us.

The last few days of the summer holiday are a time of reflection. We tend to spend them alone without plans or friends to play with. Perhaps we will indulge ourselves with one final treat, or simply hunker down at home to prepare for what is to come, sharpening pencils, buying new gym shoes, sorting out the uniform. This year's "back to school" seems doubly significant as my 11-year-old starts secondary school and we will all have to navigate uncharted territory. New buildings, new teachers - by subject this time rather than form - a timetable, new friends to make and an entirely different route to school which she will soon have to, and want to, navigate alone. She is not just a year older, but embarking on a whole new phase of her life. Starting secondary school feels like the official beginning of her adolescence and the number of future happy summers together seem even more limited.

Countless parents complain about the length of the summer holidays. They are no doubt looking forward to next week's new round of school runs, packed lunches and delegating responsibility for their children to the local education authority. It may be an unfashionable admission, but the school holidays are never long enough for me.

fields.headline: Shopping is the new snogging
fields.standfirst: Britain's teen magazines have stopped using sex to sell. But last weekend's Sugar Show - billed as the biggest gathering of teenage girls in Britain - showed they have found new ways to win the loyalty of 13-year-olds.  Dee O'Connell reports
fields.trailText: Britain's teen magazines have stopped using sex to sell. But last weekend's Sugar Show - billed as the biggest gathering of teenage girls in Britain - showed they have found new ways to win the loyalty of 13-year-olds.
fields.body:
The girl squirms as her mother applies a moistened handkerchief to the corner of her mouth: "Muuum," she hisses. But this is not a child on her way to kindergarten: this is a teenager en route to the first-ever Sugar Show, billed as the largest-ever gathering of teenage girls in Britain. Her mother dabs her carefully glossed mouth, the girl rolls her eyes under shiny lids and makes a bolt for the doors. She doesn't want to be held back from the serious business she came here for: this show is all about shopping, socialising, music, boys, fashion and beauty.

Sugar is the country's biggest-selling teen magazine, and aims its brightly packaged mix of beauty, fashion, real-life stories and celebrity gossip at girls who fall between the jelly-and-ice-cream innocence of the younger child and the emancipated state of the older teenager. For the teenagers in the packed exhibition hall in Islington, north London, it's what the magazine is billing as "the total ultimate day", but the girls seem unsure what to do with it. Some of them drift around the shop-lined periphery in twos and threes, arms linked, dressed identically. When one stops to finger a diamante belt, the other has started towards the Tampax stand with its virtual make-over computers.

Mahnie, 14, from London, has taken a break from a summer spent hanging out in Fulham ("for the boys and the shopping") to come to the show. She delivers her verdict: "We looked around the shops. They're not that good. Kind of expensive," she pronounces before disappearing off to watch a band.

Parents can be forgiven for drumming their fingers and thinking anxiously, "Never mind the shops, what about the sex?" Teenage magazines have a lurid history, but there is a distinct lack of explicit sexual content at the show. Instead, the brand names are out in force - the show is sponsored by Tommy Girl (Tommy Hilfiger's perfume), along with Tampax, Kodak, Schwarzkopf and Storm, the model agency.

The landscape has certainly changed since the days when Peter Luff, a Tory MP, was prompted to table his periodical (protection of children) bill in 1996. Sugar had been on the market for two years then, and the level of public concern over the sexual content of the magazines was at a peak. Moral panic set in as newspaper article after newspaper article urged parents to examine their daughters' reading material.

Few liked what they saw, and interpreted much of the content as incitement to early sexual experimentation. Luff, himself the parent of a magazine-reading daughter, filed a complaint with the Teenage Magazines Arbitration Panel, newly formed to monitor the content of the controversial publications. The case centred on a Sugar real-life story (headline: "I slept with 40 boys in three months"). At the time, the story was not untypical - four years later, articles like it have all but disappeared from Sugar and its kind.

Angela McRobbie, an academic expert on girls' magazines and professor of communications at Goldsmith's College, London, attributes the transition to self-regulation. "I suspect some decision was made to pull back from the emphasis on sex and snogging and the question then is, what do we replace it with? The answer is an interest in products and consumer culture."

With a weekly income of £11.69, the average 13-year-old represents easy pickings for retailers. According to McRobbie, there are signs of a concentrated attempt to hook younger people. "The mainstream chains are finding it difficult in a fragmented market when they can no longer rely on their adult consumers and younger people are the most obvious target," she says.

On the main stage a girl band is being introduced to the throng of strappy vest tops and pony tails below. This is the "fantastic Fem@il, performing their latest single," enthuses the announcer. The penny, or rather the pound, drops with the girls. If they were unsure of the part they were meant to play, they are in no doubt now. They lean disinterestedly on the railings, adjust their hairclips and form a ring of "impress me" faces. Fem@il leave to a round of scattered applause. The atmosphere changes dramatically when the MC returns holding a Tommy Hilfiger duffel bag. "Who's gonna pout for £26 worth of Tommy goods?" he asks. The girls comply, throwing poses straight from a Britney Spears video with great enthusiasm and expertise. They don't appreciate being sold to, but they have no problem working it for the freebies. Francesca Luppi, 12, sitting cross-legged in the queue for a free Tommy Girl makeover, speaks for many. "I haven't really bought anything yet," she says. "But you get lots of free stuff".

Most of the girls have their eye on the booty: Sugar Show bags are ubiquitous and the girls are intent on cramming them with as much as possible. At the Tampax stand, some are trying to salt away enough to last until the menopause. But anything that costs money is assessed with the energetic gravity of a market-stall veteran.

Kodak, promoting its disposable cameras, is offering the opportunity to be photographed with a male model. But there's a catch: the girls must buy a £5 camera to pose with "the boy of their dreams". The three 12-year-olds at the stand are unconvinced. "£5? Between three of you? No? Really, no?" the blonde woman behind the counter asks brightly. The girls shrug and slink away. That's enough for a new mascara, an eighth of the average weekly income for a 12-year-old.

Parents can rest assured. This is how Mahnie and her friends balance their budgets. The big brand names may consider them a crucial spending group, but there is plenty of evidence at the Sugar Show that today's teenage girls have their own value-for-money agenda. Even more important, though, is the boy-seeking agenda.

There is a carefully selected handful of male models at the show for the girls' delectation. Their pin-ups and mini-interviews appeared in the last issue of Sugar, so the girls know their names and a few juicy details (such as the fact that "gorgeous Trent prides himself on being a bit of a smoothie"). Without due care for their personal safety, the boys go walkabout and their appearance prompts much tossing of hair and girlish rivalry.

The trio from the Kodak stand re-appear in the middle of the melee. One of them produces a pen from her rucksack and is rewarded with an autograph and a hug from Trent. She struggles to put her pen back in her bag, which has become tangled in a big knot with the sleeve of her jumper - but by the look on her shiny, red face, she doesn't care. She got to meet the boy of her dreams after all and it didn't cost her a penny. She is probably glad that someone took the trouble to clean the corner of her mouth this morning.
