It transpires that he not only has a parole officer, but also a social worker and a psychiatric nurse. It turned out that none of them knew what my neighbour had been up to. But how would they? Did they expect him to volunteer the information himself? It is now widely accepted that people suffering mental illness should, wherever possible, be treated in the community. But for this to work, they need to be well supported and supervised; otherwise they, and the community in which they live, will suffer. Though my neighbour has shown no inclination to change his behaviour, the housing department may have to abandon its eviction case because social services would like him to stay put and see if they can "make it work". The care professionals were oblivious to what was going on. It clearly wasn't working. And how can it now? Intervening after he has harassed, threatened and intimidated for eight months is way too late. Instead of being cared for in the community, my neighbour has been allowed to run amok and become a threatening presence. The way he is now perceived in the street can hardly be helping his paranoia. And as for me, I wonder can these same professional carers really expect me to move back, next door to a man who has several times sworn he will kill me?  Neil Arksey writes fiction for older children and teenagers. His new book, Playing On The Edge, is published this month by Puffin, price £4.99

webTitle: Falklands hero leads police reruitment drive

fields.headline: Falklands hero leads police recruitment drive
fields.trailText: The Government will tonight launch its first-ever national police recruitment campaign with a hard-hitting advertisement featuring the Falklands hero, Simon Weston.
fields.body:
The Government will tonight launch its first-ever national police recruitment campaign with a hard-hitting advertisement featuring the Falklands hero, Simon Weston.

The £7m campaign, created by M&C Saatchi, uses testimonies from celebrities to illustrate the difficulty of working for the police force. It uses the strapline, "Could you?", and is designed to attract quality recruits rather than large numbers of applicants.

The first commercial shows Weston talking about how difficult he would find it to deliver news of the death of a relative. "People say I'm brave. I've had to deal with a lot in my life," he says. "But to go round to somebody's house, to tell a man that his wife and child have been killed by some drunken idiot in a car crash How do you do that?" The words, "Could you?" then appear on screen followed by a telephone number and website address.

Other commercials feature former footballer John Barnes and former EastEnders star Patsy Palmer. Barnes is shown talking about how he would react to a crowd of drunken football hooligans, while Palmer says that she would find it difficult to talk young people out of taking drugs.

The agency's brief was to raise the status of the police force as a career, with particular emphasis on recruiting more women officers and people from ethnic minorities. The Home Office aims to recruit an additional 9,000 police officers over the next three years.

eMC Saatchi, the agency's online specialist, and LIDA, its direct marketing operation, were also involved in the creation of the campaign. Media planning and buying are being handled by COI roster agencies.

M&C Saatchi was appointed to the account in June after seeing off challenges from J Walter Thompson, BMP DDB and Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R. The high-profile appointment put the agency back on the government advertising map after it was shunned for five years because of its associations with the Conservative party.

fields.headline: OgilvyOne opens viral marketing unit
fields.trailText: OgilvyOne, the WPP-owned direct marketing agency, has launched a unit dedicated to advising clients on how to use digital word-of-mouth to promote their products.
fields.body:
OgilvyOne, the WPP-owned direct marketing agency, has launched a unit dedicated to advising clients on how to use digital word-of-mouth to promote their products.

So-called viral marketing uses giveaway gimmicks, cartoons and jokes to tempt email users to the advertiser's web site. An email linking to the site is initially sent to a small number of carefully chosen people in the hope they will pass it on to other email users with similar interests.

John Owrid, a management partner at OgilvyOne, will oversee the unit. "Traditional marketing strategies have never translated well to the web," he said. "Broadcasting is costly and high-risk. As the net's infrastructure gets stronger, viral marketing gets easier and the rewards for those who can do it properly, get bigger.

"The internet was designed to be a system for individuals to exchange ideas. If you look at the bulk of traffic on the net, most of it is community: People talking to each other. The most popular application on the net is e-mail."

OgilvyOne has just launched a viral marketing campaign for Felix cat food using an email of a downloadable cartoon cat named Felix. Virtual Felix will initially be mailed to a small group of cat lovers, who are urged to email him on to friends. Sent as an attachment to PC users, the programme sees Felix playing around on the computer desktop. It contains a link to the Felix website, where users can register to receive extra toys and other accessories for their cartoon cat. This enables the company to record detailed information about cat lovers for direct marketing purposes.

Felix's European marketing manager, Calum Macrae, said: " The internet is not designed to be a broadcast medium. Using it as such is an expensive and often futile process. The net is a many-to-many medium. Viral communications exploit the fact that the strongest influence will always be word of mouth. This is a way of adding structure to word of mouth. "

webTitle: Fayed sues for release of US 'Diana files'

fields.headline: Fayed sues for release of US 'Diana files'
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed has announced legal action against the United States government in a bid to obtain "secret" documents concerning the death of Diana, Princess of Wales and his son, Dodi.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed has announced legal action against the United States government in a bid to obtain "secret" documents concerning the death of Diana, Princess of Wales and his son, Dodi.

The Harrods owner also called on the American people to lobby President Bill Clinton to release Diana and Dodi security files.

On the eve of the third anniversary of the fatal Paris car crash, Mr Fayed repeated his claim that the Princess and his son were murdered.

In a video-recording played at a Washington DC news conference today, he said: "Federal agencies of the United States of America possess documents which may provide vital information as to the cause of the deaths of Diana, Princess of Wales and my son Dodi.

"They refuse to release many of them on the basis that they would jeopardise national security.

"I believe they are withholding some of the documents at the request of the British Secret Service who cannot afford to let the truth be known."

Mr Al Fayed said he would have liked to have been in Washington in person but the anniversary of the death of his son and Diana was "too painful for me to speak in public". He called on Americans to write to their Congressional representatives and President Clinton to ask them to release documents held by US agencies such as the Central Intelligence Agency, National Security Agency, and Defence and Justice departments.

Diana and Dodi died when a Mercedes driven an employee of Mr Al Fayed, Henri Paul, crashed in the Alma tunnel in Paris on August 31, 1997.

French police found that Paul, deputy head of security at the Paris Ritz, who was also killed in the crash, had been drinking heavily and was speeding.

But Mr Fayed has refused to accept the French findings, repeatedly alleging that British security services engineered the crash.

In today's statement he claimed that US intelligence agencies, using the most sophisticated satellite systems, spied on Diana, monitored many of her conversations and apparently passed the information to MI6.

He also accused the US Department of Justice of failing to fully investigate and prosecute alleged fraudsters who attempted to extort £12 million from him by offering for sale alleged CIA documents.

A CIA spokesman told Sky News that he "emphasised" that suggestions of CIA involvement in the crash were "ludicrous".

Mohamed Al Fayed's website

fields.headline: Publicis shareholders approve Saatchi acquisition
fields.trailText: Publicis's shareholders have voted unanimously in favour of acquiring Saatchi & Saatchi, clearing the way for the two companies to merge next month.
fields.body:
Publicis's shareholders have voted unanimously in favour of acquiring Saatchi & Saatchi, clearing the way for the two companies to merge next month.

The $2bn (£1.4bn) deal, which was first announced in June, is expected to be finalised on September 12, with an exchange of shares between the two companies. Saatchi & Saatchi shareholders approved the friendly takeover on August 16.

Publicis's shareholders also voted for a formal name change to Publicis Groupe to reflect the new profile of the French company, which will consist of several independent networks. Publicis earlier this year bought US agency network Fallon McElligott.

Separately, Saatchi & Saatchi chairman Robert Seelert was made a member of the Publicis advisory board.

fields.headline: Alex Allan
fields.standfirst: Alex Allan, Tony Blair's digital envoy, was live online on Friday 4 August answering questions on Britain's e-commerce strategy, putting government services online and working on using the net to improve the democratic process. This is an edited transcript of the discussion; click here here to read the full debate and have your say and here to look at Alex Allan's homepage.
fields.trailText: Alex Allan, Britain's e-envoy, was live online on Friday 4 August answering questions on Britain's e-commerce strategy, putting government services online and working to use the net to improve the democratic process
fields.body:
quizzer
Why does Britain need an e-envoy? Isn't the point of the internet that it develops without regard to governments and national boundaries?

AlexAllan1
Let me start with quizzer's question about why we need an e-envoy at all. Tony Blair felt that the internet was at the heart of so many different policies that he needed someone who could take an overview of what was going on and what the Government needed to do. We work with Departments like the Department of Trade and Industry on the market and business framework, with Department for Education on skills and so on, and we are driving the plans to get government itself online.

I think there's a job that needs doing here - we're certainly not short of work :-)

rmarriott1
Mr Allen, how does it feel to be appointed e-envoy by a Government which is doing everything it can to destroy the UK's future in the developing new e-commerce economy? The following measures are doing real and lasting damage to the UK's competitiveness in the new e-business world:

1. IR35 - this vindictive tax measure is driving UK IT consultants out of the country in droves. I myself start a contract in New Jersey in October, leaving the UK precisely because of IR35. My skills - distributed database systems and the integration of large databases with the web.

2. NICs on share options - bad policy which is inhibiting investment by high tech. companies. Real examples - Veritas has halved its investment in the UK because of this measure and Cisco is rumoured to have diverted its investment plans to Eire for the same reason.

3. RIP Bill - it is simply stupid for the UK Government to attempt to go it alone in internet regulation - far better to wait for international agreement. As a consequence of RIP, four UK based ISPs have threatened to move offshore.

Mr Allen, I suggest you resign in protest at the Government making your job impossible.

AlexAllan1
rmarriott1 - as you can imagine I get more email about those three topics than almost anything else.

Let me take the RIP Bill first. The Government has amended the law as it went through Parliament, in response to all the points that were made. That's the essence of our Parliamentary system. I don't believe the Act is a threat to e-commerce in the UK. The Home Office has made clear that the burden on ISPs will not be excessive and the Treasury has agreed to additional funding. And the provisions on keys have been modified to make it clear that what's wanted is plain text. We do need to make sure we have laws in place to deal with paedophiles, terrorists etc.

I'll answer on share options and IR 35 in a moment.

rmarriott1 Obviously we need to make sure we have laws in place to deal with paedophiles, terrorists etc. My point is that internet as a global phenomenon can only be regulated at the supra-national level. Either this should be done through GATT or the WTO, or through a new body set up for the purpose. The reason ISPs are threatening to leave the UK is not because of the cost, but because of the regulatory disadvantage UK only action places them in.

RealAlien Mr Allan, In your response to the question re: the RIP bill, the bill itself shows how out of touch the Govt. is with IT and the Internet in general.

Even the US has said that the powers in the RIP bill are excessive. Taking as examples our European partners, France and others have relaxed their laws, while the UK has greatly increased, are they then wrong or being complacent? In the global market, companies can and are going to countries that are seen to be reducing regulatory burdens. Sadly, the UK is increasing while our EU partners and the rest of the world are reducing theirs. The powers are not needed, and anyone with knowledge of the Internet will know that paedophiles, terrorists and criminals will not be deterred or even caught by the additional powers. It is merely an amateur attempt to regulate.

AlexAllan1
rmarriott1 and RealAlien - Most other countries have or are planning provisions to require ISPs to enable emails to be intercepted: we are not alone on this. Witness the interest in the US in the FBI's use of the so-called Carnivore system to plug into ISPs and intercept email traffic. The Dutch have passed legislation on this in very similar terms to our own.

JosephSW
Dear Alex,

I run a small IT consultancy (I am not a disguised employee), and have a real opportunity to join a new e-Commerce company in this country.

The new company has been approached by a thriving marketing company to act as its e-Commerce partner. However, because of the new IR35 measures my existing business will not be able to afford to fund the initial startup costs... the company profit is being taxed at 52% before it can be re-invested for growth.

Is it clear to you now that IR35 is killing new e-Commerce ventures in Britain?

jrharding

Mr Allen The danger of a _genuine_ business falling foul of IR35 is real and the penalties are horrendous (personal bankruptcy and even imprisonment) How are _genuine_ small business's supposed thrive in this environment?

AlexAllan1
I promised to come back on IR35 and share options, though don't expect easy solutions.

On IR35, the Inland Revenue have made it clear that if someone meets the tests for self-employment, then they won't be affected. I know some contractor groups have sent in model contracts which seem to meet that test, though others seem to feel this won't help them. We'll have to monitor how that works out in practice. It's not a question of attacking entrepreneurship: there was some genuine abuse by people avoiding employees income tax and NICs by becoming contractors even though the reality was that they were in the same position as before. The difficult bit is stopping that without hitting people who have genuinely set up businesses.

AlexAllan1
On share options, the Treasury made some changes in the last Budget. In many circumstances we now have very similar effective rates of taxation to the US. But I know there are areas where firms feel the new rules still discourage firms from using share options as a way of giving all their employees a stake in the success of the company. Stephen Timms, the Financial Secretary to the Treasury, led a review of this and I'm sure will want to monitor how the new arrangements are working.

rmarriott1
Mr Allen, thank you for your response on the IR35 issue, but you must realise that this is a dog's breakfast of a tax change. If there were real abuses to be dealt with, proper and genuine consultation with representatives of the businesses affected could have framed workable regulations. IR35 is arbitrary, unfair and discriminatory. Affected businesses are left in a state of dire uncertainty since the IR in their wisdom will not vet contracts until they have been signed. If a contract is affected by IR35 it is impossible to action it profitably. Mr Allen, are you in any way independent, or do you have to slavishly endorse every silly thing the Government does?

AlexAllan1
On IR35, I'll make sure the Treasury see the comments posted here, and will discuss with them the arrangements for monitoring the impact.

Nsedgwick
Alex, I think the IR35 comments cannot be expressed loudly enough. The new IR35 legislation is causing huge uncertainty and doing real damage to entrepreneurial Web/e-commerce/IT businesses such as mine. The PCG now has over 11,000 members who stand opposed to these draconian measures. In reality the number of legitimate businesses damaged by IR35 is much greater.

Something must be done and quickly! NS.

SysOut
You have used the arguments of paedophiles and terrorists to interfere with our rights and our privacy - those are the arguments of dictators - it is totally unacceptable.

Were you to do the same with people's post - people receiving letters with envelopes which had been opened, you know very well what the reaction would be.

This is immoral and disgusting - until now the speciality of police states.

The fact that others (usa) do it, does not make it right or better - where is the moral backbone we expect?

AlexAllan1
Sysout - I'm sure I won't convince you, but the law for some time **has** allowed the police or other agencies to get a warrant to intercept letters or phone calls. They can only do this when they have evidence that someone is engaged in crimes such as I mentioned. What the RIP Act does is extend this to other forms of communication.

SysOut
Thanks Alex for your answer - I will remain, as I hope others will, vigilant of government activity in matters of data protection and privacy..

ALargeElk A quick flick through http://www.parliament.uk shows that less than half of MPs can be contacted by email and only about 80 have their own homepages. Do you feel that 'to improve the democratic process', educating those at the top would be a good place to start?

AlexAllan1
ALargeElk asked about MPs email addresses and home pages. I have had discussions with the Parliamentary Office of Science and Technology and with the Hansard Society about this. They are keen to encourage more MPs to use the internet and are looking at ways to help them get online. Many MPs are interested but worried about how they would handle what they fear could be a flood of email. There is quite a lot that can be done to make handling emails easier, so I hope we will start to see more MPs publishing their email addresses. I was in Rutland yesterday and the (admittedly small!) Council told me that every one of them published email addresses on their web site.

dsi
What do think about using the internet as a tool for those with disabilities, enabling them to get access to information they might not otherwise be able to get?

AlexAllan1
dsi - there's certainly a lot that can be and is being done to help people with disabilities take advantage of all the opportunities offered by the internet. The Government's web site guidelines have been drawn up in consultation with the RNIB and others so as to make sure that Government sites are as accessible as possible to everyone.

It's a great tool for communication, as you say.

fmk
alex - do you believe your task is being needlessly undermined by daft reporting of minor security hitches which, if they happened in the real world, wouldn't merit a para in your local paper, but because they happen in the e-world, they are front page news (ref barclays this week)?

AlexAllan1
fmk - I agree that far too much is made of some of these incidents, and it does all serve to make people fearful of doing transactions online. Clearly, firms need to have proper security procedures in place so that people can be confident their personal data won't be misused. But it's far more dangerous giving your credit card to a waiter in Soho than dealing with a reputable web site using SSL for example.

Paulos
How and by when will the voting process change for the electorate. If not via the internet, is there not scope for voting via the national lottery terminals - it strikes me that apathy at the ballot box could be re-addressed in this day and age. What are you recommending to your boss?

AlexAllan1
Paulos - I agree we need to think imaginatively about how we can make voting easier, so that more people will participate. I was in Australia for their last election, and they have compulsory voting. I don't see that going down well here, but what was striking was the way they made voting so much easier - people could vote anywhere in their State rather than just at a single polling station. Various experiments were made during the recent local elections here and we need to analyse what worked best. There' quite a lot more to do - a rolling electoral register where you can change your registration details online is one example of a service I believe would make things easier.

meethoss
At this moment in time, it is very expensive to hire a company to bring E-Commerce in to your site, and very complicated to set it up yourself. Will you be providing any sort of solution to this?

E-Commerce is a vital part of trading and many companies are not taking advantage of it due to the complications, expenses and lack of knowledge on the subject.

AlexAllan1
meethoss - it needn't be that expensive for small firms to add e-commerce to their sites. I guess I'd better not endorse individual companies, but I visited a firm in Yorkshire recently who had a really easy system for setting up and hosting e-commerce sites at a reasonable price. Local Business Links should be able to provide advice on what firms in any region are doing that.

meethoss
In regard to your statement about voting on-line, I would like to point out the fact that the Internet is not the safest environment and is susceptible to attacks from "crackers" from all over the World. How would you ensure that the election was totally secure and that it could not be changed to influence votes for certain parties?

AlexAllan1
meethoss - we'd clearly need to make absolutely sure about the security of online voting before we enabled that. I believe the technologies are or will be there, but they also need to command public acceptance. The Electoral Commission would need to be closely involved to rule out any possibility of fraud or manipulation.

jrharding
Mr Allen

Do you feel that the government is depending far too much on large consultancies for advice on IT. When its obvious they have vested interests in directing the government in directions which will be profitable for themselves?

AlexAllan1
jrharding - we certainly want to make sure we get consultancy advice from a wide range of firms. The new Office of Government Commerce has a role to play in this. I'm very conscious of your point: a small consultancy firm recently explained to me that the bureaucracy and number of meetings involved in tendering for Government contracts made it impossible for them to afford to do so. We want to tap into innovative thinking in this area.

AlexAllan1
Thanks - I've got to sign off now. I've found it interesting and I'm sorry if I haven't been able to answer all the questions.

You are welcome to email me on e-envoy@open.gov.uk - without interception!

Is it clear to you now that IR35 is killing new e-Commerce ventures in Britain? jrharding Mr Allen The danger of a _genuine_ business falling foul of IR35 is real and the penalties are horrendous (personal bankruptcy and even imprisonment) How are _genuine_ small business's supposed thrive in this environment? I know some contractor groups have sent in model contracts which seem to meet that test, though others seem to feel this won't help them. We'll have to monitor how that works out in practice. It's not a question of attacking entrepreneurship: there was some genuine abuse by people avoiding employees income tax and NICs by becoming contractors even though the reality was that they were in the same position as before. Nsedgwick Alex, I think the IR35 comments cannot be expressed loudly enough. The new IR35 legislation is causing huge uncertainty and doing real damage to entrepreneurial Web/e-commerce/IT businesses such as mine. The PCG now has over 11,000 members who stand opposed to these draconian measures. In reality the number of legitimate businesses damaged by IR35 is much greater. Something must be done and quickly! NS. SysOut You have used the arguments of paedophiles and terrorists to interfere with our rights and our privacy - those are the arguments of dictators - it is totally unacceptable. Were you to do the same with people's post - people receiving letters with envelopes which had been opened, you know very well what the reaction would be. Do you feel that 'to improve the democratic process', educating those at the top would be a good place to start? AlexAllan1 ALargeElk asked about MPs email addresses and home pages. Council told me that every one of them published email addresses on their web site. dsi What do think about using the internet as a tool for those with disabilities, enabling them to get access to information they might not otherwise be able to get? AlexAllan1 dsi - there's certainly a lot that can be and is being done to help people with disabilities take advantage of all the opportunities offered by the internet. The Government's web site guidelines have been drawn up in consultation with the RNIB and others so as to make sure that Government sites are as accessible as possible to everyone. It's a great tool for communication, as you say. fmk alex - do you believe your task is being needlessly undermined by daft reporting of minor security hitches which, if they happened in the real world, wouldn't merit a para in your local paper, but because they happen in the e-world, they are front page news (ref barclays this week)? AlexAllan1 fmk - I agree that far too much is made of some of these incidents, and it does all serve to make people fearful of doing transactions online. What are you recommending to your boss? AlexAllan1 Paulos - I agree we need to think imaginatively about how we can make voting easier, so that more people will participate. I don't see that going down well here, but what was striking was the way they made voting so much easier - people could vote anywhere in their State rather than just at a single polling station. Various experiments were made during the recent local elections here and we need to analyse what worked best. There' quite a lot more to do - a rolling electoral register where you can change your registration details online is one example of a service I believe would make things easier. meethoss At this moment in time, it is very expensive to hire a company to bring E-Commerce in to your site, and very complicated to set it up yourself. Will you be providing any sort of solution to this? E-Commerce is a vital part of trading and many companies are not taking advantage of it due to the complications, expenses and lack of knowledge on the subject. AlexAllan1 meethoss - it needn't be that expensive for small firms to add e-commerce to their sites. I guess I'd better not endorse individual companies, but I visited a firm in Yorkshire recently who had a really easy system for setting up and hosting e-commerce sites at a reasonable price. Local Business Links should be able to provide advice on what firms in any region are doing that. meethoss In regard to your statement about voting on-line, I would like to point out the fact that the Internet is not the safest environment and is susceptible to attacks from "crackers" from all over the World. How would you ensure that the election was totally secure and that it could not be changed to influence votes for certain parties? AlexAllan1 meethoss - we'd clearly need to make absolutely sure about the security of online voting before we enabled that. The Electoral Commission would need to be closely involved to rule out any possibility of fraud or manipulation. jrharding Mr Allen Do you feel that the government is depending far too much on large consultancies for advice on IT. AlexAllan1 jrharding - we certainly want to make sure we get consultancy advice from a wide range of firms. The new Office of Government Commerce has a role to play in this. We want to tap into innovative thinking in this area. AlexAllan1 Thanks - I've got to sign off now. I've found it interesting and I'm sorry if I haven't been able to answer all the questions. You are welcome to email me on e-envoy@open.gov.uk - without interception!

webTitle: Ford boss to appear in product recall ad

fields.headline: Ford boss to appear in product recall ad
fields.trailText: Jac Nasser, the chief executive of Ford, is to appear in a high-profile advertising campaign in an attempt to stem the disastrous effects of the Firestone tyre fiasco on the car manufacturer's public image.
fields.body:
Jac Nasser, the chief executive of Ford, is to appear in a high-profile advertising campaign in an attempt to stem the disastrous effects of the Firestone tyre fiasco on the car manufacturer's public image.

Firestone, which supplies tyres for Ford's hugely popular Explorer model in the US, was forced to recall 14.4 million tyres after they were linked to dozens of road deaths. The alleged tyre failures involved the tread falling off, particularly in hot weather conditions, in states including California, Florida and Texas.

Nasser is to appear in a 90-second TV commercial to give his personal guarantee that Ford is doing everything in its power to resolve the problem. The latest advertising updates consumers on the Firestone product recall, and sees Nasser saying the progress being made was good, "but not good enough".

Vehicles sold in the UK are not thought to be at risk as they are fitted with a different tyre model from those sold in the US.

fields.headline: Hopeful dance with destiny
fields.standfirst: Broadband is the net entrepreneur's new hope. Imogen O'Rorke looks at efforts to woo backers
fields.trailText: Broadband is the net entrepreneur's new hope. Imogen O'Rorke looks at efforts to woo backers
fields.body:
'London, UK, July 17 2000. Fifty hopeful broadband entrepreneurs aim to leave a central London hotel with projected deals worth between $1m and $10m...," puffs the press release from First Tuesday, the match-making club which new media types love to slate (but still be invited to, of course).

Why should we care this time? Is it because broadband - the bandwidth technology which will enable video and film to be streamed down the phone line to our PCs and mobile phones - is the new path to profitability? The word that can throw the lifeline to floundering dot.coms and launch a flotilla of new start-ups in an otherwise suicidal market?

Surely Channel 4's E-Millionaire Show, which culminated in a spectacular dot.bomb, was proof enough of what happens when an immature industry is over-hyped and sold to the public as lottery tickets? After its growing pains, the market has matured, as has, so we are told, First Tuesday which has announced a merger with Yazam, a first-stage investor, and is preparing for a relaunch in the autumn.

So Thursday's event in the Park Lane Hotel was not the cattle market it used to be. The "young pretenders" have been put through two screening tests (only the top 10% to 15% of the 300 entrepreneurs who applied were chosen) and only half of the venture capital firms who registered have been invited.

Lines of numbered tables are laid out with refreshments in the ballroom at which the hopefuls wait attentively for the VCs to sign their "dance cards". They have 10 minutes to entice their dates to a further meeting before the gong is sounded and everyone moves round one place. Almost civilised. "Thank God. I was starting to feel too old for all of that networking stuff," confides David Phillips, 30-something CEO of music portal iCrunch. He is about to go into the third of his 10 pitches that day.

After introducing his team, he launches into the routine. iCrunch, which aggregates and exploits digital music rights in the alternative European market, sees "a natural extension from dance music to dance culture and being able to go deep and vertical in terms of the music and the lifestyle", he explains. "We then add value to it by bundling it with editorial, content and community."

Phillips, a former AOL executive, is no web wannabe. Just 16 months old, iCrunch is working with 50 music labels, and has deals with HMV and EMusic. It is talking to "everyone" from telecoms companies to magazine publishers, including a major music channel with whom it is discussing "a branded channel distribution deal".

The pitches are slick and seamless. Phillips disarms a question about competitors by comparing Peoplesound.com to the "meat market" of the early First Tuesdays. "This is a more mature, filtered environment... We are getting in the new acts, breaking in the new talent."

So where are the wannabes? Sometimes you can tell them by their overly-austere suits. DataKlick online marketing research's managing director, Lisanne Davie - aged 23, with punk red hair and a chin stud but tucked into a smart outfit - and her portly director of strategy, David Liley, could fit the description. Davie approached Liley with her idea nine months ago when he was running a web design agency and she was a junior telemarketing officer. He gave up his job to join her.

DataKlick, however, is a serious contender. Its vision for making market research "fun" for its "cohort of willing consumers" is by paying them to take part in market research surveys (from 50p to £3 for a few minutes) and using broadband multimedia streaming. Their company's competitive edge, they maintain, is that it is 20% cheaper than its rivals and can get results within two hours. The second VC they met today offered to write a cheque out for several million if they fulfilled certain criteria which they believe they can meet within six months. Flushed with excitement, they don't want to count their chickens but at this rate they could be floating in 18 months.

By far the wackiest pitch was IndiaGeek.com, a broadband channel which according to a co-founder, Farrukh Dhondy, will provide "satirical and innovative" programming for the Indian diaspora. Dhondy, a columnist on the Asian Age and former Channel 4 commissioning editor, formed AMI Net last year with Shekhar Kapur, director of Bandit Queen and Elizabeth, and the CEO, Mohan Chopra, backed by money from "friends and fools". It has offices in London and Delhi.

"We are building for the day when the computer becomes the TV screen. Whatever John Birt says, the TV is never going to run successful interactive shows," says Dhondy. Despite the postmodern name, IndiaGeek claims to be coming up from grassroots. "There's a new consciousness. Indians are obsessed with Bollywood and yet only one in 100 films succeeds - people are looking for something new." The web channel will stream short films, animations, drama, comedy and "tasteful erotica". "Nothing is sacred. We're going to slaughter a lot of holy cows. We are going to do revelations, to take the cover off: corruption, cruelty, slavery, oppression, wife-burning - give India its first burst of investigative and observational documentary films." Free from government censorship, IndiaGeek can go where the Asian networks fear to tread.

Dhondy believes they have no competition, "because no one knows what to do with broadband. They see it as a dumping ground for Bollywood films or old TV shows. They are not exploiting the grammar of the net."

IndiaGeek is hoping to close a deal for $3m in the next few months for a spring launch. From an investors' perspective, too, the day has been fruitful. "I've seen six companies," says Thomas Kenney, of Nokia Ventures, who is over from the US to "check out the cool technologies, applications, services for 3G mobile internet - investing at an early stage". He has arranged second meetings with four start-ups. Kenney is "surprised" by the 2% brokerage fee that First Tuesday has introduced. "In the States, if a VC agency asked for that it would be 'get outa here!'." But in Europe, he concedes, it is a different market.

At the end of the day, no one is exactly walking out with a deal. If they performed well, they have a handful of business cards and invitations to meet up. The next generation of net entrepreneurs crawls into the lobby, exhausted, with their mobile phones beeping, but encouraged that when it comes to broadband a bit of the old dot.com fever still exists.

fields.headline: Police manpower shortages
fields.standfirst: For the first time television ads are being used to persuade people to join the police. Julian Glover looks at the recruitment crisis in the police force
fields.trailText: For the first time television ads are being used to persuade people to join the police. We look at the recruitment crisis in the police force.
fields.body:
So the police are having trouble hiring?
Police numbers are falling - down by 1,678 last year - causing a double-headed problem for home secretary Jack Straw. First, he has promised repeatedly that police numbers would rise; instead the number of officers has slipped from 127,158 in England and Wales in April 1997, to 124,418 today. Second, levels of politically sensitive types of crime, such as violent crime, are rising sharply. So the decline in police numbers has become a political hot potato.

Why are numbers falling?
For all sorts of reasons. One factor is the devolved structure of Britain's police forces. By law the home secretary cannot determine the number of officers each force employs and some chief constables have chosen to spend any spare cash on new technology rather than extra manpower. Another cause has been a squeeze on police budgets - until recently some forces have had to sack officers rather than recruit them. This problem was partly solved by the comprehensive spending review, which provided extra funds for recruitment. But the most significant cause of the problem seems to be the fact that people simply aren't as keen to join the police as they once were.

Why is this?
Money has something to do with it - police salaries have not kept pace with private-sector ones, particularly in the south-east, where the recruitment crisis is at its most serious. Officers can no longer afford to live in some of the areas they police. The reputation of the police has taken a knock, too - partly as a result of the report into the Stephen Lawrence affair and revelations about police corruption, but also through the way the police are portrayed on television. Ministers complain that programmes such as The Bill are simplistic and misleading.

So what are they doing about it?
Launching an advertising campaign, for one thing, under the title Could You? Police. These are designed to show police officers as heroic public servants rather than dubious stick-wielders. The TV ads feature real-life heroes such as Falklands veteran Simon Weston and footballer John Barnes describing how despite their own success, they still admire the work done by the police.

But the army's had ads for years. Are they really the answer?
Probably not - but they make it clear that the government has recognised the problem. The real solution probably lies in spending more money. Already the allowance given to officers working in London has been increased, leading to a 28% increase in applications to the Metropolitan police. The home secretary has also set aside cash to recruit 9,000 new officers across England.

And that if that doesn't work?
It's been suggested that the police might recruit the next generation of bobbies from abroad - leading to a rash of speculation about a culture clash between unarmed British officers and their gun-toting European colleagues. In fact the police would only be adopting a practice which has long helped staff other public-service professions, such as medicine, and there seems to be little chance that the streets will be filled with French flics anytime soon.

webTitle: Media investors offer free ads to ease 'cash burn'

fields.headline: Media investors offer free ads to ease 'cash burn'
fields.standfirst: Advice and funding to be swapped for equity
fields.trailText: A collection of leading media lights has banded together to set up an investment fund for new media and technology companies, offering free advertising space and advice as well as cash.
fields.body:
A collection of leading media lights has banded together to set up an investment fund for new media and technology companies, offering free advertising space and advice as well as cash.

Participants in the £36m Accelerator Media fund include Channel 5, radio group GWR, Guardian Newspapers, publisher of the Guardian and the Observer, Jazz FM and Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group.

The investment fund has raised some £20m in cash and a further £16m in advertising space in return for equity in Accelerator.

The investors are expected to float Accelerator on the stock market within 12 to 18 months to raise further cash.

An important aim of the fund is to reduce the "cash burn" of marketing costs in the early months of a company's development.

"There's been an awful lot of money spent on marketing by start-ups - and perhaps not all of it wisely due to the goldrush mentality," said Philip McDannell, the former managing director of Chrysalis Group, who is running Accelerator.

"With this business we have huge leverage among the media companies who are involved and we have experts who can give terrific advice."

Other senior management figures include Alan Brydon, former media director of advertising agency AMV BBDO, and Charles McIntyre, the financier who helped Mr MacKenzie raise the cash for TalkRadio - now renamed the Wireless Group.

The cash element has been provided by Gold-Zack, a financial services group which is listed on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

Accelerator will target companies which are at second stage financing instead of raw start-ups.

This is not the first time a media company has offered advertising space in return for equity in internet start-ups, but Accelerator claims to be the first in which a range of firms have joined together. The Accelerator investors own poster sites, TV channels, radio and press operations.

Mr McDanell said the market for fledgling new media and technology companies had reached sensible levels after the mania of last year and the first three months of 2000.

"There is still the potential for high returns, although not necessarily of the fantastic kind we were looking at the start of the year.

"This is a realistic time to invest," he said.

"People are not asking for crazy money in return for a small percentage in their company, and the whole approach to business has become more mature."

The Accelerator fund will target both business to business and the less fashionable business to consumer markets but will require some demonstrable revenues streams before investing.

Channel 5 announced its own plans at the start of the year to offer equity for publicity, accepting stakes in internet start-ups as a payment for promotion.

Neither is the idea limited to media concerns. Linklaters, the law firm, is accepting equity in lieu of fees for its professional services.

The investors are expected to float Accelerator on the stock market within 12 to 18 months to raise further cash. An important aim of the fund is to reduce the "cash burn" of marketing costs in the early months of a company's development. "There's been an awful lot of money spent on marketing by start-ups - and perhaps not all of it wisely due to the goldrush mentality," said Philip McDannell, the former managing director of Chrysalis Group, who is running Accelerator. "With this business we have huge leverage among the media companies who are involved and we have experts who can give terrific advice." Other senior management figures include Alan Brydon, former media director of advertising agency AMV BBDO, and Charles McIntyre, the financier who helped Mr MacKenzie raise the cash for TalkRadio - now renamed the Wireless Group. The cash element has been provided by Gold-Zack, a financial services group which is listed on the Frankfurt stock exchange. Accelerator will target companies which are at second stage financing instead of raw start-ups. This is not the first time a media company has offered advertising space in return for equity in internet start-ups, but Accelerator claims to be the first in which a range of firms have joined together. The Accelerator investors own poster sites, TV channels, radio and press operations. Mr McDanell said the market for fledgling new media and technology companies had reached sensible levels after the mania of last year and the first three months of 2000. "There is still the potential for high returns, although not necessarily of the fantastic kind we were looking at the start of the year. "This is a realistic time to invest," he said. "People are not asking for crazy money in return for a small percentage in their company, and the whole approach to business has become more mature." The Accelerator fund will target both business to business and the less fashionable business to consumer markets but will require some demonstrable revenues streams before investing. Channel 5 announced its own plans at the start of the year to offer equity for publicity, accepting stakes in internet start-ups as a payment for promotion. Neither is the idea limited to media concerns. Linklaters, the law firm, is accepting equity in lieu of fees for its professional services.

fields.headline: 'Distressing' TV advert banned by watchdog
fields.trailText: A Sony TV advert for a digital music player has been banned for being "insensitive" and "unacceptably offensive" to recently bereaved viewers.
fields.body:
A Sony TV advert for a digital music player has been banned for being "insensitive" and "unacceptably offensive" to recently bereaved viewers.

The commercial featured a speeded-up sequence of a teenager being rushed to hospital and into intensive care for resuscitation.

The independent television commission upheld 25 complaints from viewers, 10 of whom said the campaign was a distressing reminder of "a close personal experience".

In the advert the emergency team were shown preparing what appeared to be equipment for cardiac shock treatment but turned out to be the music player. They touched the earpieces together before placing them in the patient's ears and playing a blast of music. The actor's body convulsed as if receiving an electric shock, and he sat up as if resuscitated.

Most of the complainants said the commercial would be distressing to the recently bereaved.

Ordering it to be suspended, the ITC said its scenes "were likely to be powerful reminders of tragedy for significant numbers of viewers".

The advertisers said they "regretted the distress to families who have been through experiences of this kind".

In November 1996, the ITC upheld complaints about Texaco adverts showing doctors trying to resuscitate a car engine. It warned against advertising "likely to act as repeated reminders of distressing personal circumstances to large numbers of viewers".

webTitle: NTL woos rival to take on BSkyB

fields.headline: NTL woos rival to take on BSkyB
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: NTL, Britain's largest cable company has approached rival pay-television firm OnDigital in the hope of setting up a marketing alliance to close the gap on BSkyB.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's largest cable company has approached rival pay-television firm OnDigital in the hope of setting up a marketing alliance to close the gap on BSkyB.

NTL is proposing to bundle its TV internet and telephone services with the OnDigital TV channels outside of its cable franchise areas. Initial conversations between the two sides were held several weeks ago.

The service would use the Microsoft set-top boxes currently in production for NTL which will include software enabling it to transmit digital television via an aerial. As well as providing its unmetered internet service, NTLworld via the TV set, the box would enable customers to receive the existing free-to-air digital services such as ITV 2 and the soon to be renamed BBC Choice.

Discussions with OnDigital centre on making the box compatible with its smart card which customers could then slot into the box to receive the pay-TV group's services as well.

NTLworld, which launched in May has so far signed up 250,000 users.

Barclay Knapp, NTL chief executive said: "We are always looking at ways of expanding ourinternet and telephony service beyond our franchise areas. We want to be able to say to customers if you want a multi channel TV service as well then call OnDigital. They have always been interested and have said when you have the whole thing wrapped up then come and talk to us."

The set top box is expected to be on offer from next year.

An OnDigital spokeswoman said the putative deal was "in the pile of a number of interesting things we could do in the future.

"Clearly for us to tie up with a telecoms company would be a logical move so we are talking to a range of other potential partners as well as NTL."

OnDigital, the joint venture between Carlton and Granada, has so far signed up 800,000 subscribers. There were indications at the weekend that the company's planned £1.5bn stock market flotation may be brought forward to the autumn.

The flotation is understood to have been put back on the agenda by the resolution of the consolidation of ITV which has left Granada and Carlton dominating the network.

Mr Knapp further damp ened speculation that there would be more consolidation in the cable industry by saying that a merger with the number two operator in Britain, Telewest, was not on the cards. "The shareholder structure of Telewest makes it very difficult to do a transaction," he said. "It's just not very realistic and if they continue to make themselves more complicated it becomes less likely. It's like making peace with a Balkan state."

He also conceded that NTL made a mistake in not launching its digital television service earlier without the add on services such as internet access which had caused the delays. Both cable companies have been strongly criticised for allowing satellite broadcaster BSkyB to surge ahead.

Mr Knapp predicted that by 2004, BSkyB would have 7m customers, the cable companies would catch up and have 12m while OnDigital would muster 3m.

fields.headline: Deschamps blasts 'impossible' Vialli
fields.trailText: Didier Deschamps has blamed the high number of games in English football and an "impossible" relationship with Gianluca Vialli for his poor season with Chelsea.
fields.body:
Didier Deschamps has blamed the high number of games in English football and an "impossible" relationship with Gianluca Vialli for his poor season with Chelsea.

The 30-year-old World and European champion, who is set to leave the international stage after France's game against England on Saturday, admitted his year spent in the Premiership frustrated him.

"In England I had difficulty showing my qualities," the Valencia midfielder told the French press. "I arrived from Italy with techniques which were useless in England, there were too many games and no break in December.

"I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with the coach Gianluca Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became."

About international team-mate Patrick Vieira, who was sent off in both of Arsenal's opening two games, Deschamps added: "A foreigner is less protected than a British player.

"It's a paradox because there are very good English referees who can perform very well in a European game but are too fussy or too lax in the Premier League. No-one really complains about it - neither the public nor the media - and I'm not here to tell them they are wrong."

fields.headline: Dennis takes on Firebox
fields.trailText: Lads' gadget website firebox.com has imparted a 5% equity stake to Dennis Publishing in exchange for being heavily promoted across the publisher's raft of magazines and websites.
fields.body:
Lads' gadget website firebox.com has imparted a 5% equity stake to Dennis Publishing in exchange for being heavily promoted across the publisher's raft of magazines and websites.

The deal, estimated to be worth around £250,000, coincides with the news that Firebox parent company, Firebox.com Holdings, has placed 20% of the company with the private investment platform EO.net, a division of Firebox incubator, NewMedia Spark.

Firebox, which is valued at £5m and has operations in the UK and Scandinavia, hopes to raise £1m through the placing, which will be put toward funding further international expansion. NewMedia Spark initially provided first round funding of £500,000 to the site in December 1999.

Firebox hopes the deal with Dennis will give it a strong marketing presence in the publisher's titles, which include Maxim, the Official Dreamcast Magazine, MacUser and Computer Shopper, and encourage its 1.2m regular readers to buy gadgets from Firebox.com.

Shares of Firebox Holdings, the first Spark investment to use the EO fund-raising platform for raising further capital, went on sale through EO.net on 29 August. "As our sales continue to grow, the fund raising will create the opportunity for new shareholders to benefit directly from the ongoing success of the business," said Michael Smith, chief executive of Firebox.

EO.net, which launched in June this year, aims to be the leading European retail distribution platform for new equity issues, both public and private.

fields.headline: Rangers set for £13m double swoop
fields.trailText: Rangers are set to complete a sensational £13m double swoop by signing Ronald de Boer and John Hartson.
fields.body:
Rangers are set to complete a sensational £13m double swoop by signing Ronald de Boer and John Hartson.

Earlier today Dick Advocaat agreed a £6m fee and personal terms with Dutch midfielder de Boer, and then followed it up by making an audacious £7m bid for Wimbledon striker Hartson. Rangers moved quickly for de Boer yesterday after negotiations between Barcelona and Manchester United broke down. A Rangers spokesman confirmed the 30-year-old midfielder had arrived at Ibrox for a medical after flying into Glasgow last night.

On his personal website icons.com, a delighted de Boer says: "My agent Rob Jansen has just completed talks with Rangers and I've agreed personal terms on a four-year contract. I'm about to undergo a medical, which is always a little bit nerve-wracking, but I've been fairly injury-free so everything should be okay on that score.

"Apparently there's a few minor issues to be sorted out between the clubs but I fully expect to become a Rangers player. I'm already looking forward to linking up with my new team-mates - but first I have to meet up with the Dutch national squad in good time for our match with Ireland at the weekend."

Meanwhile, Hartson is reportedly having talks with Rangers this afternoon with a view to completing a £7m move from Wimbledon. And the 25-year-old Wales international striker's agent Jonathan Barnett is believed to be heading to Glasgow ready to clinch the deal.

Hartson was on the verge of joining Tottenham last March but the move broke down when he failed a medical. His season ended miserably when he was sent off during Wimbledon's penultimate game of the season at Bradford.

He was later charged with misconduct by the FA over a pre-match bust-up in the players' tunnel before the game.

webTitle: England stars - and understudies - on course for a big pay-day

fields.headline: England stars - and understudies - on course for a big pay-day
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's first gossip column of the week, Charles de Lisle has an exclusive report on how the England team will be raking in £18,000 a man if they win the series against the West Indies, and finds out what Geoff Boycott really said about the Headingley Test pitch
fields.trailText: It won't be uppermost in their minds as the fifth Test at The Oval begins tomorrow, but a series victory would see England's players sharing an ECB bonus of no less than £215,000 - about £18,000 per man for those who've played all five Tests against the Windies.
fields.body:
It won't be uppermost in their minds as the fifth Test at The Oval begins tomorrow, but a series victory would see England's players sharing an ECB bonus of no less than £215,000 - about £18,000 per man for those who've played all five Tests against the Windies.

For the likes of Atherton, Stewart, Caddick and Gough that's a cheque not to be sniffed at, even in these lucrative days. Nasser Hussain (four Tests) should have about £14,000 (minus 40 per cent tax) to spend on, say, a September holiday. Dominic Cork (four Tests if selected tomorrow) will have no trouble paying for his wedding last Monday, or maybe that delayed honeymoon with his second wife.

Even players discarded along the way - Mark Ramprakash, Nick Knight, Robert Croft, Andy Flintoff et al - stand to pick up several thousand pounds each if the series is won.

By winning two Tests the side has already pocketed £60,000, plus £42,000 in prize money from the outgoing sponsors Cornhill, not to mention some extras (Man of the Match awards are worth £4,500). Victory at The Oval would also yield another £30,000 bonus for winning a Test, a further £21,000 from Cornhill, and almost certainly another Man-of-the-Match. All this cash goes into the "team pool", which is split between players under a formula drawn up by them - not their bosses.

The scheme, introduced two years ago, is the ECB's biggest foray yet into performance-related pay. But, oddly perhaps, the bonuses bear no relation to individual performance. They're carved up entirely according to how many matches each member of the team has played.

The prospect of yet more bonuses will be good for team morale in other ways, too. Experienced players overlooked for the first batch of central contracts - Graham Thorpe and Dominic Cork in particular - will see them as overdue compensation for the fact that, under a quirk of this season's new pay regime, they're being paid less than was on offer last summer.

This week isn't the first time England's stars have had a serious chance of earning big bonus money. By pulling off that sensational 2-1 victory against South Africa two years ago, they landed a £200,000 performance bonus, then paid by sponsors Vodafone.

Since then, though, a lot of big bucks have gone uncollected. An Ashes series win in 1998-99 would have brought a further £200,000 for the players' kitty, but they lost 3-1. Then there were the twin disasters of the World Cup (partly caused by a pay dispute) and the New Zealand series last summer. The ECB confirms that England's solitary victory, in the first Test at Edgbaston, would have been worth a £19,000 bonus. But the series was lost 2-1, after much anguish, and the series win bonus of £100,000 stayed in the ECB's ever-bulging coffers.

Last winter's South Africa tour (a 2-1 defeat) saw the same pattern re-emerging. The £200,000 series win incentive was never in much danger of being carried off by Hussain's side, though the now-tainted victory at Centurion in the final Test produced £19,000 from the board - and heaven knows how much for the bookies and punters. And the two-Test Zimbabwe series? England's 1-0 win wasn't even deemed worthy of a bonus scheme.

Should England claim the £215,000, it will bring a particular smile to the face of Simon Pack, whose sudden departure as the ECB's first - and maybe last - International Teams Director was announced late last week. The bonuses are his baby. "I prefer not to call this an incentive scheme," he said when the £200,000 for the 1998 South Africa series was announced. "The England team need no such encouragement to give their total commitment. 'Performance -related bonus' is a better description."

Boycott clashes with committee again

Once again Geoffrey Boycott and the Yorkshire committee are at odds. Boycott privately feels that the committee with which he had so many battles during his playing career is taking his name in vain as it attempts to douse down criticism of the Headingley pitch on which the fourth Test finished in two days.

Against Boycott's clearly expressed wishes, the embattled committee is leaning on the master grafter's reputation to fend off criticism of the cracked wicket on which England bowled out the West Indies for 61. The committee's hitherto undisclosed defence centres - rather surprisingly, perhaps, given that he was fired in 1986 - on Boycott. According to them, a batsman with the technique, determination and experience of Boycott - scorer of 22 Test centuries for England including four in 10 Tests at Headingley, where he averaged 59.80 - would have been perfectly capable of dealing with that surface. Their line is that even against Ambrose and Walsh, Boycott would have been quite able to score "a big hundred".

The actual top score in the match was 76 by another straight-batted Yorkshireman, Michael Vaughan. But in the committee's view, there was nothing wrong with the strip: West Indies' batsmen simply weren't good enough to cope with the moisture in the thundery overhead atmosphere, and the consequent swing.

Boycott, who rarely agrees with anyone, takes a completely different view, and still sounds irritated to have his good name taken in vain. In his view, the wicket was unworthy of a county game, let alone a Test.

During play at Headingley, Boycott - whose duties as a TalkSport radio commentator include pitch reports - paid a rare visit to the committee box, where his private views were made known with customary candour. Returning to the commentary box, believing that hardly anyone had really listened, he blew off steam to fellow broadcasters. Although he withheld news of the committee exchanges from listeners, he told colleagues off air: "I certainly couldn't make a hundred on this bloody wicket. No one could!"

By yesterday Boycott, 59, was a mite calmer. "The pitch was very disappointing," he told me. "England's win was quite exciting and dramatic, and quite exhilarating. But a two-day Test is only all right if it's a one-off. Cricket can't afford more of them."

Could he have prospered on that surface? "Not my problem," he replied briskly, trying to bring the interview to a swift end. Or as he put it: "I'm not going to write your website for you." For that, read tacit confirmation of those private opinions.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For last Friday's Grapevine, with stories on the cricket correspondent who missed Headingley, Shane Warne's long-haul commute to work at Canterbury, cricket's Do of the Week, and why David Gower has become the "new boy" again, click here.

"Not my problem," he replied briskly, trying to bring the interview to a swift end. Or as he put it: "I'm not going to write your website for you." For that, read tacit confirmation of those private opinions. Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). webTitle: Hume to quit Northern Ireland assembly

fields.headline: Hume to quit Northern Ireland assembly
fields.trailText: The SDLP leader, John Hume, is to resign his Northern Ireland assembly seat, the party confirmed today.
fields.body:
The SDLP leader, John Hume, is to resign his Northern Ireland assembly seat, the party confirmed today.

The Nobel peace prize laureate will remain as leader of the party, MP and MEP.

SDLP officials said Mr Hume had decided to step down as an assemblyman for Foyle in the near future to reduce his workload. "In recent times, John has had to cut down his workload. He will continue as MP and MEP and there is no question whatsoever of him stepping down as party leader," an SDLP spokesman said.

Mr Hume's decision came a year after he received hospital treatment for a ruptured intestine.

West Belfast MLA Dr Joe Hendron expressed "sadness" at Mr Hume's decision. Dr Hendron, who also served with Mr Hume in the Commons as West Belfast MP between 1992 and 1997, revealed that the SDLP leader had informed assembly colleagues of his decision at a meeting at Stormont yesterday.

"I am saddened that John has had to cut down on his workload for health reasons. He will be sorely missed on the assembly benches but will still be at our meetings in Stormont as party leader and will be remaining as an MP and MEP," the West Belfast assemblyman said.

"The SDLP is very proud of John's achievements as a party leader. As one of the principal architects of the Good Friday Agreement, his contribution to political life in Northern Ireland and to the island of Ireland has been outstanding.

"I make no apologies for saying that I consider him to be one of the greatest Irishmen of the past 200 years - at all times, he has promoted the interests of Catholic, Protestant and dissenter and I know it is breaking his heart to see the recent violence, the loyalist feud."

A campaigner for reconciliation in sectarian Northern Ireland, Mr Hume has staked his reputation on the peace process, winning respect from republicans and loyalists alike.

A former teacher, Mr Hume came to prominence through the civil rights movement in the late 1960s, when Catholics demanded substantial changes to the way Northern Ireland was run. He helped to found the moderate nationalist Social Democratic and Labour party in 1970, taking over as its leader in 1979.

In 1988, Mr Hume began a series of contacts with the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, laying the groundwork for the current peace process. The SDLP leader's strategy was to try to persuade Sinn Fein that the problem in Ireland was not so much the British presence but the divisions between the people of Ireland, unionist and nationalist.

webTitle: Former HTV execs in talks with Granada

fields.headline: Former HTV execs in talks with Granada
fields.trailText: Former HTV executives have trumped Carlton Communications by holding talks with Granada Media over buying the ITV franchise.
fields.body:
Former HTV executives have trumped Carlton Communications by holding talks with Granada Media over buying the ITV franchise.

Huw Davies and David Jenkins worked as senior directors at the Wales and west of England franchise, and have appointed KPMG as advisers for any takeover bid. The move follows their acquisition of Channel Television, the licence for the Channel Islands, in June.

Granada must offload HTV under the terms of its acquisition of United News & Media's ITV interests in July. Rival broadcaster Carlton was the favourite to buy HTV, after the collapse of its proposed merger with United earlier this summer scuppered plans for increasing audience share.

Other potential bidders for HTV include SMG, the former Scottish Media Group, which owns Scottish Television and Grampian, though regulators might raise an eyebrow at Granada's 18% stake in the company.

Independent Television Commission regulations state that no company can control more than 15% of the ITV audience. Granada's £1.75bn deal with United added Meridian and Anglia to its Yorkshire, Tyne Tees, LWT and Granada franchises, but HTV took it over the regulator's limit.

Granada hopes the restrictions will be relaxed following the publication later this year of a government white paper on broadcasting and telecommunications regulations. If the rules on franchise ownership are loosened, Granada would be interested in re-acquiring HTV.

fields.headline: Carl Barks
fields.standfirst: Disney animator who helped develop Donald Duck and other close relatives
fields.trailText: Disney animator who helped develop Donald Duck and other close relatives
fields.body:
Carl Barks, who has died aged 99, was a Disney animator whose character Scrooge McDuck, Donald Duck's uncle - a Scottish, red-coated, wispy-haired, stick-wielding fellow - was a natural development from Barks' earlier work, when he was responsible for developing Donald Duck himself. When Barks took on Donald, the duck was thin with a long beak. It was Barks who made him more cartoon-like - rounder, with a much fatter beak - and who defined his comic character.

Barks felt that everyone could identify with Donald Duck: "He is everything, he is everybody; he makes the same mistakes that we all make. He is sometimes a villain, and he is often a real good guy, and at all times he is just a blundering person like the average human being, and I think that is one of the reasons people like the Duck."

Barks wrote for Disney as well as illustrating. In fact, it was Walt Disney himself who suggested Barks move to the story department because they needed good gag writers more than animators. It was while there that he wrote the Donald Duck short, Modern Inventions; later he invented Duckburg and extended Donald's family to include his three young nephews Huey, Dewey and Louie.

In 1939, Barks wrote a typescript story, Pieces of Eight, in which Mickey, Donald and Goofy run a tavern in a small, New England village. It is a fine tale of an errant parrot, hidden treasure, cross-dressing and a sea chase. It never got made, but in 1941 Oscar Lebeck of Western Publishing, the firm that published Disney's comics and stories every month, saw in it the material for something to follow up his firm's successful comic book, Mickey Mouse and the Phantom Blot. The script was adapted for Donald and his nephews, and Barks, with Jack Hannah, created the comic book Donald Duck Finds Pirate Gold (1942). After this, Barks left Disney to concentrate on writing and illustrating comic books full time.

It is a paradox of our times that these comic books, once available on every American news-stand and often the only means by which audiences could keep up with the characters whose screen releases were tightly controlled, are now wrapped in Cellophane and kept below glass because of the sums they fetch. Meanwhile the cartoon films, with the advent of video cassettes and DVD, are there for the asking.

The imagination which Barks let loose in these books perhaps owes something to his early life in rural Oregon, where his father was a wheat farmer. After leaving home at 15, he worked as a rancher, logger, then railroad repairman. He had loved drawing as a boy, and by the early 1930s he was selling cartoons to the Calgary Eye-Opener.

His work brought him to the Disney studios in 1935, a year after Donald had first appeared in The Little Wise Hen. Barks's eye for a gag and a story quickly had him out of the ruck of animators, and he worked on Snow White, Bambi and Fantasia as well as three-dozen Donald shorts, including Donald's Nephews (1938) and Mr Duck Steps Out (1940).

After moving to work full-time on the comic book series for Western Publishing, he created such characters as McDuck, the burgling Beagle Boys, and Gyro Gearloose, who is aided by a walking lightbulb.

Barks - with as much a Looney Tunes spirit as a Disney one - found inspiration in everything. Steeped in the world of Saturday-morning cinema, his work has had a distinct influence on American artists and film-makers, even though none of them would have known his name at the time; anonymity is the cartoonist's lot - a necessary mask if characters are to take flight.

Barks retired from working full-time on cartoons in the mid-60s and turned to a new art - painting oils of his cartoon figures. Over the years he found an extraordinary market for them. Barks brought all the vim of a Picasso to these oils and prints which command high prices. To some tastes they are gaudy, not in the same spirit as the original story frames, but if you had $250,000 to spare then Barks might have been persuaded to conjure up a scene in which McDuck is seen in his money-feathered nest. As this splendid bird once put it, "no man is poor who can do what he likes once in a while. I like to dive through my money like a porpoise and throw it up and let it hit me over the head."

Barks's so-called retirement, which also saw him working until the very end on new comic strips, lasted longer than most working lives. In 1994 he visited Europe - his first trip - on a Disney tour to celebrate Donald's 60th birthday.

Barks's third wife died in 1993. He is survived by a daughter

fields.headline: Hague challenges government over adoption
fields.trailText: William Hague today challenged the government to bring forward a bill to speed up the "politically correct" adoption process - or face one devised by his own party.
fields.body:
William Hague today challenged the government to bring forward a bill to speed up the "politically correct" adoption process - or face one devised by his own party.

Speaking in Gravesend, Kent, the Conservative party leader said adoption must be made easier for childless couples. He argued that for too long youngsters in care had been let down by government, in homes and through a lack of education.

Mr Hague told the Catholic Children's Society's familymakers section - which prepares traumatised children for adoption or for long-term fostering - how he would make adoption easier for childless couples.

He said it was wrong that children in care sometimes had to wait three years before they could be adopted, despite there being a long list of responsible, stable, loving families who would take them on.

"Conservatives want to make sure that the first consideration in adoption cases is the protection of children's interests at the heart of loving families," he said. "We want to tear up the politically correct rulebook that exploits children for the sake of an irrelevant social agenda. We need to act now for the sake of our children's future."

He added: "I am calling on the government to bring forward its own proposal for an adoption bill in the coming session of parliament. If they do not, the Conservative party will bring forward our own legislation by backing a private member's bill incorporating our proposals."

Mr Hague said it was a "shame on all of us" that a quarter of the prison population was made up of people who had been in care. "We let children down when we send three quarters of children in care into the world with no educational qualifications," he said.

A document outlining the Conservatives' strategy described as a "scandal" the three years it can take for an adoption to go through.

Every child in care for 12 months should have an adoption plan and youngsters should have access to charities, church organisations or another family. The Conservatives would also separate local authorities' ownership of care homes from their social services responsibilities.

And they would abolish the government's home detention curfew scheme, preventing child sex offenders from being released into the community before they have served their sentences. The use of mandatory life sentences for first and second-time sex offenders would be increased.

The government had said "many of the right things" on these issues, Mr Hague said, but it was letting young people down by failing to act now.

But Mr Hague admitted that the Tories' much heralded "tax guarantee", the promise to reduce taxes as a proportion of national income, would not be featured in the party's draft manifesto.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said the Tories could not be trusted. "Whatever guarantees William Hague tries to run away from this autumn, he can't run away from the fact that the Tories remain committed to cutting £16bn worth of British public services," he said.

Mocking Mr Hague's recent claims that he had once drunk 14 pints of beer a day, Mr Prescott said: "As Billy the Fizz tries to recover from his 14-pint summer hangover, people will remember that you can't trust the Tories."

fields.headline: Salvation Army
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the quasi-military charity spreading the word of the Lord
fields.trailText: 1. If you ever harboured a dream of rising through the ranks of the Salvation Army, but worried that your spouse might not be so keen, today is your lucky day.
fields.body:
1. If you ever harboured a dream of rising through the ranks of the Salvation Army, but worried that your spouse might not be so keen, today is your lucky day.

2. The Christian group has today announced a radical reform that will allow its officers to marry outside the organisation for the first time in its 135-year history.

3. Methodist minister William Booth founded the army last century in London's deprived east end.

4. The Salvation Army (so called after 1878) was set up as a quasi-military mission to feed and house the poor. To this days its members sign up to the Articles of War.

5. It's not all uniforms and brass bands. As their UK website says: "You don't have to wear a funny hat or blow a bugle - not even salvationists have to do that."

6. There is plenty that they cannot do: drinking, smoking and gambling are all forbidden.

7. But as the army is a broadly tolerant organisation, they do sell their magazine War Cry in pubs to bring the good news of Jesus Christ to places where people meet.

8. Why would you join? Paul Waters from South Africa says: "My parents were members - and their parents, and their parents."

9. He is one of a million members in 107 countries worldwide who pledge their lives to the army.

10. In its work the army feeds, houses, educates and gives medicine to a small - but not insignificant - number of the world's poor regardless of their faith or religious background.
